''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' | followed_by = ''[[Joe 90]]'' | related = ''[[Gerry Anderson's New Captain Scarlet]]'' | website = hide }} '''''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons''''', often referred to as '''''Captain Scarlet''''', is a 1960s British science-fiction television series produced by the [[AP Films#Century 21|Century 21 Productions]] company of [[Gerry Anderson|Gerry]] and [[Sylvia Anderson]], [[John Read (producer)|John Read]] and [[Reg Hill]]. First broadcast on [[ATV Midlands]] from September 1967<ref name="Bentley, 118" /> to May 1968,<ref name="Bentley, 90">Bentley 2001, p. 90.</ref> it has since been transmitted in more than 40 other countries, including the United States, Australia, New Zealand and Japan.<ref name="Bentley, 119" /> Characters are presented as [[marionette]] puppets alongside [[scale model]] sets and [[special effects]] in a filming technique that the Andersons termed "[[Supermarionation]]". This technology incorporated [[solenoid]] motors as a means of [[Lip sync|synchronising]] the puppet's lip movements with pre-recorded dialogue.
Set in 2068,<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" /> ''Captain Scarlet'' presents the hostilities between [[Earth]] and a race of [[Martian]]s known as the [[Mysteron]]s. After human astronauts attack their city on [[Mars]] due to a misunderstanding, the vengeful Mysterons declare war on Earth,<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" /> initiating a series of reprisals that are countered by Spectrum, a worldwide security organisation. Spectrum boasts the extraordinary abilities of its primary agent, [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]]. In the [[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|first episode]], Scarlet acquires the Mysteron healing factor of "retro-[[metabolism]]" and is thereafter considered to be virtually "indestructible", being able to recover fully from injuries that would normally be fatal.<ref group="e" name="Winged Assassin" />
''Captain Scarlet'', the eighth of ten puppet series that the Andersons produced during the 1950s and 1960s, was preceded by ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' and followed by ''[[Joe 90]]'' and ''[[The Secret Service]]''. In terms of visual aesthetic, the series represented a departure from ''Thunderbirds'' on account of its use of non-[[caricature]]d puppets sculpted in [[Realism (arts)|realistic]] proportions.<ref name="HowsWhys" /> Re-run a number of times in the UK<ref name="Bentley, 119" /><ref name="Bentley, 122" /><ref name="Bentley, 125" /> and purchased by the BBC in 1993,<ref name="Bentley, 122" /> the 32-episode series has entailed tie-in merchandise since its first appearance, from dolls<ref name="Marketing" /> to original novels<ref name="Titles" /> and [[comic strip]]s in the [[Century 21 Publications]] children's magazine, ''[[TV Century 21]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 102" />
In comparison to ''Thunderbirds'' and other earlier series, ''Captain Scarlet'' is generally considered "darker"<ref name="Cambridge" /> in tone and less suited to child audiences due to stronger on-screen violence and themes of extraterrestrial aggression and [[interplanetary war]].<ref name="Lesterdemon" /> The transition in the puppets' design has polarised critical opinion and drawn a mixed response from former production staff,<ref name="CrimeTV" /><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 151" /><ref name="Peel, 244" /> while the concept of an indestructible protagonist has also been called into question.<ref>Sangster and Condon 2005, p. 166.</ref><ref name="Peel, 246"/> However, the series has been praised for its inclusion of a multinational, multiethnic puppet cast and its depiction of a [[utopia]]n future Earth.<ref name="Bould, 219" /><ref name="Bould, 220" /><ref name="WomenInSpace" /> Having decided to revive the series in the late 1990s,<ref name="Bentley, 123" /> Gerry Anderson supervised the production of a computer-animated [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]], ''[[Gerry Anderson's New Captain Scarlet]]'', which was broadcast in the UK in 2005.
==Plot== {{Main|List of Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons episodes}}
In the [[The Mysterons|first episode]], a team of ''[[Zero-X]]''<ref group="n" name="Zero-X">The ''[[Zero-X]]'' and its lander craft, the Martian Exploration Vehicle (MEV), appear in the first ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' film, ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go]]''. Production documentation from ''Captain Scarlet'' confirms that the MEV that appears in "[[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|The Mysterons]]" is the same vehicle, which places this series in the same [[fictional universe]] as ''Thunderbirds'' (Bentley 2001, p. 59), set in 2065. Spectrum personnel biographies in Bentley's ''The Complete Book of Captain Scarlet'' also place the events of ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]'' (set in 2064) and ''[[Fireball XL5]]'' (set in 2063) in this universe (Bentley 2001, pp. 46–47, 50).</ref> astronauts investigate the surface of [[Mars]] in 2068 after unidentified radio signals emanating from the planet are detected on Earth.<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons">{{cite episode|title=The Mysterons|episodelink=The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by [[Gerry Anderson|Gerry]] and [[Sylvia Anderson]]. Directed by [[Desmond Saunders]]|airdate=29 September 1967}} Episode 1.</ref> The source is discovered to be an extraterrestrial base, which is attacked and destroyed when the explorers mistake a harmless sensor device for a weapon.<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" /> The inhabitants of the settlement, the [[Mysteron]]s, are [[sentient]] computers that form a [[Group mind (science fiction)|collective consciousness]].<ref name="Bentley, 43" /> They are the remnants of the original Mysteron race, extraterrestrial life forms that originated in a galaxy other than the Milky Way and maintained their colony on Mars for 3,500 years before abandoning the planet at the turn of the 20th century.<ref name="Bentley, 43" /> Possessing partial control over matter, the Mysteron computers draw on their power of "reversing matter" to rebuild the complex before vowing revenge for the unwarranted aggression.<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" />
Reversing matter, also described as "retro-metabolism",<ref group="e" name="Winged Assassin">{{cite episode|title=Winged Assassin|episodelink=Winged Assassin|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by [[Tony Barwick]]. Directed by [[David Lane (director)|David Lane]]|airdate=6 October 1967}} Episode 2.</ref> allows the Mysterons to re-create the likeness of a person or object in the form of a facsimile that is under their control. This ability is used to conduct a "war of nerves" against Earth, in which the Mysterons issue threats against specific targets (from world leaders and [[military installation]]s to whole cities and continents) and then destroy and reconstruct whatever instruments are required (whether human or object) to execute their plans. The presence of the Mysterons is indicated by two circles of green light (the "Mysteron rings") that trail across scenes of destruction and reconstruction. Although the Mysterons are able to manipulate events from Mars, their actions on Earth are usually performed by their replicated intermediaries.
''Zero-X'' mission leader [[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]], who ordered the attack on the base, becomes the Mysterons' primary agent when they seize control of his mind during the encounter on Mars.<ref group="n" name="CBMysteronisation">The transformation of [[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]] from human to Mysteron is indicated by a paling of the character's face and a deepening of his voice to match that of the Mysterons.</ref><ref name="Bentley, 43">Bentley 2001, p. 43.</ref><ref name="Bentley, 47">Bentley 2001, p. 47.</ref> Before the events of the series, Captain Black held a senior officer rank in Spectrum, an international security organisation inaugurated in 2067<ref group="e" name="Flight to Atlantica">{{cite episode|title=Flight to Atlantica|episodelink=Flight to Atlantica|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Leo Eaton|airdate=30 April 1968}} Episode 30.</ref> that mobilises all its personnel, vehicles,<ref group="n" name="Vehicles">[[Spectrum Pursuit Vehicle]]s (SPV) and [[Fictional military aircraft#Angel Interceptor|Angel Interceptor]] fighter aircraft are two of a number of vehicles that Spectrum has at its disposal. The [[Spectrum Patrol Car]] (or Saloon Car, acronym either SPC of SSC) is used for unarmed land travel, while the Maximum Security Vehicle (MSV) and Yellow Fox, an unmarked security transport disguised as a fuel tanker, are used to protect [[Mysteron]] targets. Additional aircraft include the Spectrum Passenger Jet, the two-seater Spectrum Helicopter and the Magnacopter for transporting larger numbers of passengers.</ref> and other resources in response to the threat posed by the Mysterons. The Spectrum Organisation is directed from [[Cloudbase]], an airborne headquarters stationed at a height of 40,000 feet above the Earth's surface,<ref group="e" name="Dangerous Rendezvous">{{cite episode|title=Dangerous Rendezvous|episodelink=Dangerous Rendezvous|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Brian Burgess|airdate=9 February 1968}} Episode 19.</ref> and has a presence in all major cities. The organisation employs operatives of many nationalities, of whom the most senior hold military ranks and colour-based codenames, are posted to Cloudbase, and answer directly to the [[commander-in-chief]] of Spectrum, [[Colonel White]].<ref group="n" name="CallSigns">In communications, Spectrum personnel use the call signal "SIG" ("'''S'''pectrum '''I'''s '''G'''reen") as their affirmative code. The negative, "SIR" ("'''S'''pectrum '''I'''s '''R'''ed"), is used less often.</ref> Cloudbase is defended by the Angels, a squadron of five female pilots code-named Destiny (squadron leader), Harmony, Melody, Rhapsody, and Symphony, who fly the [[Fictional military aircraft#Angel Interceptor|Angel Interceptor]] fighter aircraft. In addition, the organisation incorporates a fleet of [[Spectrum Pursuit Vehicle]]s (SPV) hidden in secret locations around the world as well as Spectrum Patrol Saloon Cars, hovercraft, transport jets and machine-gun equipped helicopters.
[[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]] becomes Spectrum's foremost weapon in its fight against the Mysterons after the events of the first episode, in which the Mysterons threaten to assassinate the [[World government in science fiction|World President]]<ref group="n" name="Politics">In the fictional universe of ''Captain Scarlet,'' power from many individual nations has been vested in a [[World government in science fiction|World Government]], which is headed by an elected World President and operates its own military and security forces. Spectrum is a unified operation established to provide a more efficient service than these separate bodies, since it is not hindered by interdepartmental red-tape (Bentley 2001, p. 43).</ref> as their first act of retaliation.<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" /><ref name="Bentley, 44">Bentley 2001, p. 44.</ref> The original Captain Scarlet is killed in a car accident engineered by the Mysterons<ref group="n" name="MysteronPresence">For the first episode exclusively, different techniques are used to indicate the Mysteron influence: in place of the Mysteron rings, the destroyed complex on Mars is reconstructed by a beam of blue light, while the deaths of the original [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]] and [[Captain Brown (Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons)|Captain Brown]] are preceded by a transition from a full-colour picture to a blue [[monochrome]]. The rings make their first appearance in the second episode, "[[Winged Assassin]]."</ref> and replaced with a re-created Mysteron likeness.<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" /><ref name="Bentley, 44" /> However, when the Captain Scarlet duplicate is shot by Spectrum officer [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Blue]] and falls to his death from a tall structure, he returns to life with the conscience and personality of the original Captain Scarlet fully restored, and thereafter he is free from Mysteron control.<ref group="n" name="CSBiography">When killed, Mysteron reconstructions are normally permanently destroyed. The one exception to this is Captain Scarlet, who can die and subsequently revive. The character's biography in ''The Complete Book of Captain Scarlet'' states that the Mysterons intended their duplicate of Captain Scarlet to be "indestructible," in contrast with their other reconstructions of deceased humans (Bentley 2001, p. 44).</ref><ref group="n" name="Survival">In the original pilot script for "The Mysterons", Captain Scarlet's revival, as well as the restoration of his original conscience, is due to the aid of an advanced computer (Bentley, p. 15). In the finished episode, he returns to life naturally, and no explanation is provided as to how he regains the conscience and personality of his pre-Mysteronised form. However, the tie-in EP ''Introducing Captain Scarlet'' indicates that after his revival, Scarlet's memories and loyalty to Spectrum are restored using Doctor Fawn's advanced computer, as in the original episode script (Bentley 2001, p. 94).</ref><ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" /> Captain Scarlet's Mysteronised body possesses two remarkable abilities: he is able to sense the presence of other Mysteron duplicates in his vicinity,<ref group="n" name="CSPowers">Scarlet demonstrates this ability in the episodes "Winged Assassin" (production number: 2), "[[Point 783]]" (production number: 5) and "[[Seek and Destroy (Captain Scarlet)|Seek and Destroy]]" (production number: 9), but no others. From the episode "[[Spectrum Strikes Back]]" (production number: 10), Captain Scarlet is apparently unaware of the presence of Mysteron agents when near to them. He demonstrates an ability to sense the presence of Mysteron agents in the five [[Extended play|EP]] records, and in the novel ''Captain Scarlet and the Silent Saboteur''.</ref> and if he is injured or killed, his retro-metabolism restores him to a state of top health. Now able to deploy suicidally reckless tactics to thwart Mysteron threats, Captain Scarlet repeatedly braves the pain of death in the knowledge that he will recover to face the Mysterons again.<ref group="n" name="BrownIndigo">During the course of the series, two other Spectrum officers are killed and reconstructed by the Mysterons in addition to Captain Scarlet and Captain Black, but their likenesses do not appear to possess the power of retro-metabolism: Captain Brown in "The Mysterons" (who explodes in proximity to, and almost assassinates, the World President in that episode) and [[Captain Indigo]] in "Spectrum Strikes Back" (who is permanently destroyed by the Mysteron Gun).</ref>
While Captain Scarlet and Spectrum defend Earth against the threat from Mars, it is found that Mysteron reconstructions are particularly vulnerable to electricity<ref group="e" name="Operation Time">{{cite episode|title=Operation Time|episodelink=Operation Time|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Richard Conway and Stephen J. Mattick. Directed by [[Ken Turner (director)|Ken Turner]]|airdate=17 November 1967}} Episode 8.</ref> and that they are detectable on X-rays, to which their biology is impervious.<ref group="e" name="Operation Time" /> Consequently, two anti-Mysteron devices, the "Mysteron Gun"<ref group="n" name="Killing">In "Spectrum Strikes Back," a line of dialogue from Captain Scarlet states that the Mysteron Gun "is the only gun that kills a Mysteron." The gun, which fires lethal beams of electrons, does not appear in any other episodes, although a similar weapon, the Electro-Ray Rifle, appears in the tie-in EP ''Captain Scarlet versus Captain Black''. Episodes both preceding and following "Spectrum Strikes Back" portray Mysteron agents as being vulnerable to conventional means of destruction, such as explosions (an example of which is in the 11th-produced episode, "[[Avalanche (Captain Scarlet)|Avalanche]]") or bullets (of which there are many examples, including the 12th-produced episode, "[[Shadow of Fear]]").</ref> and the "Mysteron Detector," are developed to aid Spectrum.<ref group="e" name="Spectrum Strikes Back">{{cite episode|title=Spectrum Strikes Back|episodelink=Spectrum Strikes Back|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Ken Turner|airdate=24 November 1967}} Episode 9.</ref> A three-episode [[story arc]] charts the uncovering of a second Mysteron complex under construction on the Moon,<ref group="e" name="Lunarville 7">{{cite episode|title=Lunarville 7|episodelink=Lunarville 7|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by [[Robert Lynn (director)|Robert Lynn]]|airdate=15 December 1967}} Episode 12.</ref> its destruction by Spectrum,<ref group="e" name="Crater 101">{{cite episode|title=Crater 101|episodelink=Crater 101|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Ken Turner|airdate=26 January 1968}} Episode 17.</ref> and efforts to negotiate with the Mysterons on Mars via a crystal power source, salvaged from the complex, which is converted into an interplanetary communication device.<ref group="e" name="Dangerous Rendezvous" /> A failed attempt at satellite surveillance of the Martian surface,<ref group="e" name="Shadow of Fear">{{cite episode|title=Shadow of Fear|episodelink=Shadow of Fear|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Robert Lynn|airdate=2 February 1968}} Episode 18.</ref> aborted military conferences<ref group="e" name="The Trap">{{cite episode|title=The Trap|episodelink=The Trap (Captain Scarlet)|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Alan Pattillo. Directed by Alan Perry|airdate=10 November 1967}} Episode 7.</ref><ref group="e" name="Flight 104">{{cite episode|title=Flight 104|episodelink=Flight 104|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Robert Lynn|airdate=1 March 1968}} Episode 22.</ref> and the sabotaged construction of a new space fleet<ref group="e" name="Noose of Ice">{{cite episode|title=Noose of Ice|episodelink=Noose of Ice|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Ken Turner|airdate=12 March 1968}} Episode 24.</ref> hinder Spectrum's plans to return to Mars, and the organisation is unsuccessful on two occasions in apprehending Captain Black.<ref group="e" name="Treble Cross">{{cite episode|title=Treble Cross|episodelink=Treble Cross|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Alan Perry|airdate=23 February 1968}} Episode 21.</ref><ref group="e" name="Manhunt">{{cite episode|title=Manhunt|episodelink=Manhunt (Captain Scarlet)|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Alan Perry|airdate=20 October 1967}} Episode 4.</ref> The penultimate episode of the series depicts a Mysteron assault on Cloudbase with the use of armed spacecraft, which is ultimately revealed to be a sunstroke-caused nightmare dreamt by Symphony Angel, one of the Angel pilots, after she is stranded in the desert following a crash of her Angel Interceptor.<ref group="e" name="Attack on Cloudbase">{{cite episode|title=Attack on Cloudbase|episodelink=Attack on Cloudbase|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Ken Turner|airdate=7 May 1968}} Episode 31.</ref> The finale is a flashback episode that ends inconclusively with regards to the war between Earth and Mars and the fate of Spectrum and the Mysterons.<ref group="e" name="The Inquisition">{{cite episode|title=The Inquisition|episodelink=The Inquisition (Captain Scarlet)|series=Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons|credits=Written by Tony Barwick. Directed by Ken Turner|airdate=14 May 1968}} Episode 32.</ref>
==Production== [[File:Gerry Anderson.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Gerry Anderson]], creator and executive producer|alt=The photograph depicts an elderly man, whose gaze is directed to the right of the camera.]]
When talks to find an American broadcaster for ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' fell through in July 1966, production for the series' second season ended with the completion of just six episodes at the behest of [[ITC Entertainment|ITC]] financier [[Lew Grade]].<ref name="Bentley, 13">Bentley 2001, p. 13.</ref> Having overseen [[Gerry Anderson]]'s work since the creation of ''[[Supercar (TV series)|Supercar]]'' in 1960 – and going on to buy his production company, [[AP Films]], during the making of ''[[Fireball XL5]]'' – Grade was enthusiastic for Anderson's programmes to be transmitted abroad, in the lucrative American market, and decided that a new concept would do more to attract potential bidders than a second season of ''Thunderbirds''.<ref name="Bentley, 13" />
As a result of the cancellation, Anderson was required to come up with an idea for another [[Supermarionation]] series. He had once been inspired by the thought of creating a live-action police drama in which the hero would have unexpectedly been murdered halfway through the series and replaced by a new lead character.<ref name="Bentley, 14">Bentley 2001, p. 14.</ref> Now giving fresh consideration to this idea, Anderson resolved that a selling point for his new series could be a character that can be killed at the end of each episode and resurrected by the beginning of the next. This, coupled with contemporary theories about the possibility of [[life on Mars (planet)|life on Mars]],<ref name="Bentley, 5">Bentley 2001, p. 5.</ref> led to the idea of an [[interplanetary war]] raging between Earth and its neighbour and a worldwide security organisation being called on to defend human civilisation. After further thought, Anderson decided that "[[Captain Scarlet (character)|Scarlet]]" would make an unusual codename for this organisation's "indestructible" agent who can come back to life, while "[[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Blue]]" could be his partner's designation. From this, Anderson reasoned that all the personnel should have colours for names so as to form the whole "Spectrum" of colours, and decided that someone called "[[Colonel White|White]]" should be the leader of the Spectrum Organisation, much in the same way that [[Electromagnetic spectrum#Visible radiation .28light.29|white light]] is composed of, and can be [[Dispersive prism|broken down into]], the colours of the [[spectrum]].<ref name="Bentley, 5" /><ref name="DVDCommentary">{{cite video|people=[[Gerry Anderson|Anderson, Gerry]]|date=2001|title=''"[[Attack on Cloudbase]]": Audio commentary''|medium=DVD|publisher=Carlton}}</ref>
{{Quote box|quote=I thought we should make a show about the [[Martian]]s, but then there were doubts being expressed by scientists as to whether the so-called [[Martian canal|"canals" on Mars]] were really man-made. Since we were well into pre-production, I came up with the idea of making the Martians invisible, so if they did come up with conclusive evidence that there was no [[life on Mars (planet)|life on Mars]], I could say, "Ha-ha, yes there is – but you can't see it."|salign=right|source=– [[Gerry Anderson]] (2002)<ref name="Billboard">{{cite journal|title=A&E's ''Captain Scarlet'' Re-Releases will be Red-Hot|first=Jim|last=Bessman|date=6 July 2002|journal=Billboard|volume=114|issue=27|page=56|publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media]]|issn=0006-2510|oclc=421998067}}</ref>|width=22.5%|align=left}}
Intrigued by the often-heard phrase "[[Hypothetical types of biochemistry|life as we know it]]", Anderson wanted to set the aliens of his new series apart from the conventional extraterrestrials of 1960s television and cinema. He therefore worked from a basis of "life as we ''don't'' know it",<ref name="Bentley, 5" /> and made the [[Mysteron]]s that were to feature in the series a race of [[sentient]] computers as opposed to organic lifeforms,<ref name="Bentley, 43" /> although this is not explicitly stated in the television episodes. The initial intention was that the original Mysteron civilisation came from another galaxy.<ref name="Bentley, 43" /> Having established a settlement on [[Mars]] in the distant past, they fled the planet centuries later, abandoning their computer complex.<ref name="Bentley, 43" />
Contemporary recollections of the Second World War proved to be an inspiration for a number of design aspects. For instance, Anderson recalled that [[RAF]] pilots had found it difficult to counter German attacks during the [[Battle of Britain]], since taking off from the ground meant that it took considerable time to intercept the enemy.<ref name="Teletronic">{{cite web|last=Marcus|first=Laurence|title=Gerry Anderson: The Puppet Master – Part 3|url=http://www.teletronic.co.uk/gerryanderson3.htm|work=teletronic.co.uk|date=October 2005|accessdate=1 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080221150836/http://www.teletronic.co.uk/gerryanderson3.htm|archivedate=21 February 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> He therefore made Spectrum's headquarters an [[airborne aircraft carrier]] called "[[Cloudbase]]".<ref name="Teletronic" /> The Mysteron rings were inspired by an advertisement for the [[Oxo (food)|Oxo]] line of food products, which included an image of the brand name sliding over a frying pan and the outline of a woman's body.<ref name="DVDCommentary" /><ref name="Teletronic" /> {{Clear}}
===Writing=== With a provisional series title of ''The Mysterons'',<ref name="Bentley, 15">Bentley 2001, p. 15.</ref> Anderson and his wife, [[Sylvia Anderson|Sylvia]], wrote a pilot script in August 1966.<ref name="Bentley, 7">Bentley 2001, p. 7.</ref> This differed significantly from the final draft of the [[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|first episode]]. Initially, it was decided that the [[Mysteron]] duplicate of [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]] would be artificially resurrected by an advanced Spectrum computer rather than reviving naturally, and that thereafter he would no longer be truly human but a "mechanical man" akin to an [[Android (robot)|android]].<ref name="Bentley, 15" /> Another early ambition was for each episode to feature a guest star voiced by a well-known actor of the day. To this end, the role of the [[World government in science fiction|World President]] in the first episode was originally intended to be voiced by the American-born actor [[Patrick McGoohan]].<ref name="Bentley, 17">Bentley 2001, p. 17.</ref><ref name="Archer, 38">Archer, p. 38.</ref>
With Anderson serving chiefly as [[executive producer]], the majority of the writing input for ''Captain Scarlet'' was provided by [[Tony Barwick]], who had previously written for the short-lived second season of ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 31">Bentley 2001, p. 31.</ref> Originally given the role of [[script editor]], Barwick went on to pen 18 of the 32 episodes himself, and was also often required to make substantial changes to other writers' work.<ref name="Bentley, 31" /> While discussing his approach to writing episodes in a 1986 interview, he drew parallels between the premise and characters of ''Captain Scarlet'' and those of ''Thunderbirds'', suggesting, for example, that Spectrum was similar to International Rescue and that the character of [[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]] was like the earlier recurring villain from ''Thunderbirds'', [[The Hood (Thunderbirds)|The Hood]].<ref name="Bentley, 31" />
===Filming=== [[File:Dinky Toys 104 Spectrum Pursuit Vehicle-Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons.jpg|thumb|[[Dinky Toys]] version of the [[Spectrum Pursuit Vehicle]] (SPV), the primary [[Armoured fighting vehicle|armoured assault vehicle]] of Spectrum. The [[AP Films#Century 21|Century 21]] special effects unit had refined its standard driving mechanism so that [[scale-model]] vehicles appearing in ''Captain Scarlet'' could produce authentic [[inertia]]l dips.<ref name="HowsWhys"/>|alt=The photograph depicts a scale toy replica of an armoured tank-like vehicle that is metallic-blue in colour, with five wheels on each side.]]
After a two-month [[pre-production]] period lasting from November to December 1966, filming on the first episode, "[[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|The Mysterons]]", began on 2 January 1967,<ref name="Bentley, 22">Bentley 2001, p. 22.</ref> with a budget of £1.5 million for the 32-episode series.<ref name="Teletronic" /><ref name="TVHeaven">{{cite web|last1=Marcus|first1=Laurence|last2=Hulse|first2=Stephen|title=''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons'': A Television Heaven Review|url=http://www.televisionheaven.co.uk/scarlet.htm|work=televisionheaven.co.uk|year=2000|accessdate=1 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629052514/http://www.televisionheaven.co.uk/scarlet.htm|archivedate=29 June 2008|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> At an average cost of £46,000 per episode, or £2,000 per minute, it was the most expensive Anderson production to date.<ref name="Bentley: Episode Guide, 119">Bentley 2008, p. 119.</ref> A month before, Anderson and his team had dropped the name "AP Films," since Arthur Provis was no longer working alongside Anderson on a full-time basis, and renamed their company "[[AP Films#Century 21|Century 21 Productions]]".<ref name="Bentley, 22" /> Many of the directors for earlier Anderson series, such as Alan Pattillo, [[David Elliott (director)|David Elliott]] and [[David Lane (director)|David Lane]], had either left AP Films or were involved in the production of ''[[Thunderbird 6]],'' the second ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' feature film, at the time that ''Captain Scarlet'' was being produced. Although [[Desmond Saunders]] and Lane were available to direct the first and second episodes, while veteran AP Films director Brian Burgess also contributed, the Andersons needed to transfer some of the more junior production personnel to replace the outgoing staff. To this effect, Alan Perry and [[Ken Turner (director)|Ken Turner]] were promoted from the camera operator and [[art department]]s.<ref name="Bentley, 32">Bentley 2001, p. 32.</ref> Directors drafted in from outside AP Films were Peter Anderson, Leo Eaton and finally [[Robert Lynn (director)|Robert Lynn]], who had worked as an [[assistant director]] on the 1958 [[Hammer Film Productions|Hammer]] films ''[[Dracula (1958 film)|Dracula]]'' and ''[[The Revenge of Frankenstein]].''<ref name="Bentley, 32" />
The [[Slough Trading Estate]]<ref group="l" name="Slough">[[Slough Trading Estate]]: {{Coord|51.5244|-0.6250|type:landmark_region:GB-NWP|name=Slough Trading Estate, Slough, Berkshire|format=dms}} (principal photography and editing)</ref> in [[Buckinghamshire]] had served as Anderson's production base since the filming of ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]'' in 1964.<ref name="Bentley, 12">Bentley 2001, p. 12.</ref> To accelerate production on earlier [[Supermarionation]] series, pairs of episodes had been filmed simultaneously on separate [[sound stage]]s, a practice that continued for ''Captain Scarlet''. Some filming coincided with the production of ''Thunderbird 6'',<ref name="Bentley, 31" /> which was recorded on a separate puppet stage and released in July 1968. Editing rooms, [[post-production]] offices and a preview theatre were housed in a separate building on the Slough Trading Estate; the crew collaborated with the [[Standard Telecommunication Laboratories]] at [[Harlow]] in [[Essex]]<ref group="l" name="Harlow">[[Standard Telecommunication Laboratories]]: {{Coord|51.779|0.128|type:landmark_region:GB-NWP|name=Standard Telecommunication Laboratories, Harlow, Essex|format=dms}} ("electronic collaboration")</ref> on the technical and electronic side of the production.<ref name="Bentley, 57">Bentley 2001, p. 57.</ref>
A third unit, headed by [[Derek Meddings]] and his assistant [[Mike Trim]], handled [[special effect]]s and [[Scale model|miniatures]] and was tasked with creating all the permanent sets and models to be used from the first episode, such as the [[Cloudbase]] interiors and scaled-down [[Spectrum Pursuit Vehicle]]s. A design innovation for this series meant that the noses of the miniature vehicles would "dip" when stopped, to imitate the sudden application of brakes and deceleration on a real-life vehicle.<ref name="HowsWhys">{{cite web|last=Wickes |first=Simon |title=The Hows and Whys of Supermarionation – Part 4 |url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=81 |work=tvcentury21.com |date=29 December 2003 |accessdate=26 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717115311/http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=81 |archivedate=17 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> The miniature of the Cloudbase exterior, which ran to six feet (1.8 m) in length, proved to be too heavy to be held up with strings and was instead supported by a metal pole.<ref name="Archer, 23">Archer, p. 23.</ref><ref name="Bentley, 21">Bentley 2001, p. 21.</ref> To transfer the [[Mysteron]] rings from script to screen, the production team acted on the advice of producer [[Reg Hill]], who suggested that a [[Reversal film|transparency]] be made that could be panned across the puppet sets using a slide projector.<ref name="DVDCommentary" />
By the time the series started broadcasting on [[Associated Television|ATV]] in September 1967, [[principal photography]] had been completed for the first 20 episodes.<ref name="Bentley, 41">Bentley 2001, p. 41.</ref> In general, turnaround for completing all the puppet shots for each episode was two weeks<ref name="TVHeaven" /><ref name="Bentley, 34">Bentley 2001, p. 34.</ref> or 11 working days.<ref name="Bentley: Episode Guide, 119" /> It was originally predicted that shooting would be wrapped within eight months,<ref name="TVHeaven" /> but filming overran until late October due to the demands of the ''Thunderbird 6'' shoot.<ref name="TVHeaven" /> While production on the next Supermarionation series, {{Nowrap|''[[Joe 90]]''}}, began in November<ref name="Bentley, 114">Bentley 2001, p. 114.</ref> it was not until early 1968 that the last episodes of ''Captain Scarlet'' were edited and completed for broadcast.<ref name="Bentley, 41" />
===Music=== [[File:Spectrum motif.png|thumb|240px|Spectrum [[leitmotif]], associated with [[Cloudbase]] and the organisation in general|alt=The image depicts musical notation of a fast-paced motif consisting of minims, crotchets and quavers.]] [[File:Mysteron motif.png|thumb|240px|Four-note [[Motif (music)|motif]] used to illustrate the presence of the [[Mysteron]]s. [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]]'s [[Variation (music)|variation]], below, emphasises the character's past as a former Mysteron.<ref name="ImageDissectors" />|alt=The image depicts musical notation of two similar motifs consisting of four notes, one featuring only semibreves and the other only crotchets.]]
Music for ''Captain Scarlet'' was composed by [[Barry Gray]], an innovator in [[electronic music]], who had scored all the [[Supermarionation]] series preceding it. The opening [[title sequence]] theme, "The Mysterons", was rendered electronically and accompanied by a [[staccato]] drum beat to introduce the lead character of [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]].<ref name="Bentley, 40">Bentley 2001, p. 40.</ref> This seven-note beat was also used to link scenes within episodes,<ref name="Bentley, 40" /> and to cut to [[Television advertisement|advertisement breaks]],<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 156">Archer and Hearn, p. 156.</ref> for which it was accompanied by a zooming image of the Spectrum logo as designed by Tony Dunsterville of the [[art department]].<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 156" /> On the subject of the beat, Anderson recalls, "When I went to the recording session, I heard the drum beat he had come up with and I thought, 'Christ, is this all he could produce?' Looking back on it, however, I can see that what he came up with worked very well."<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 156" />
The [[closing credits]] theme, "Captain Scarlet", underwent significant change after the completion of the first 14 episodes. The first version had been mainly instrumental, with the words "Captain Scarlet!" sung in time to the aforementioned staccato drum beat after which a [[vocoded]] repetition of the words "Captain Scarlet!" provided by Gray himself would be heard.<ref name="Bentley, 40" /> This was then revised as a song performed by a London-based pop group The Spectrum, assembled by [[RCA Victor]]<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 157">Archer and Hearn, p. 157.</ref> as an imitation of the American band [[The Monkees]],<ref name="Bentley, 40" /> who happened to share their name with the organisation that appears in ''Captain Scarlet''.<ref name="Bentley, 40" />
In addition to the main theme, Gray scored [[incidental music]] for 18 episodes of ''Captain Scarlet'' between March and December 1967.<ref name="Bentley, 41" /><ref name="TVCentury21">{{cite web |last=de Klerk |first=Theo |title=Complete Studio-Recording List of Barry Gray |url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=67:complete-studio-recording-list-of-barry-gray&catid=116:barry-grey&Itemid=182 |work=tvcentury21.com |date=25 December 2003 |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m00eATOK?url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=67:complete-studio-recording-list-of-barry-gray&catid=116:barry-gray&Itemid=182 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Musical accompaniment for the remaining 14 episodes was achieved by re-using these completed tracks as well as music from previous Anderson productions such as ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 41" /> In composing his incidental music, Gray made extensive use of two contrasting, yet similar, themes to illustrate Spectrum and the [[Mysteron]]s.<ref name="Soundtrack">{{cite AV media notes|title=Captain Scarlet: Original Television Soundtrack|others=[[Barry Gray]]|year=2003|author1=Titterton, Ralph |author2=Mallett, Tim |page= 3|publisher=Silva Screen Records|location=London}}</ref> In their notes to the soundtrack release, Ralph Titterton and Tim Mallett suggest that the music is dominated by a "[[Military band|military]] feel", with an emphasis placed on percussion, [[Brass instrument|brass]] and wind instruments, by contrast to the full [[orchestra]]l sound of the ''Thunderbirds'' score.<ref name="Soundtrack" /> With the exception of the four-note Mysteron [[Motif (music)|motif]], Gray generally restricted his use of electronic synthesisers, including an [[Ondes Martenot]], to space sequences, preferring traditional instruments for [[Earth]]-bound action.<ref name="Bentley, 40" /> Captain Scarlet's motif, heard in both versions of the end credits theme and the incidental music, is a [[Variation (music)|melodic variation]] on the Mysteron theme, emphasising Scarlet's history as an ex-Mysteron.<ref name="ImageDissectors">{{cite web|last=Weedon |first=Robert |title=Spectrum is Green |url=http://www.imagedissectors.com/article/69 |work=imagedissectors.com |date=20 February 2010 |accessdate=20 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qO9TFvZH?url=http://www.imagedissectors.com/article/69 |archivedate=10 June 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
Awarding the soundtrack CD release a rating of four stars out of five,<ref name="Allmusic" /> Bruce Eder of the website [[AllMusic]] describes the collection of theme and incidental music as "a strange mix of otherworldly '[[music of the spheres]]', late-50s/early-60s '[[Space age pop|space-age pop]]', '[[British Invasion]]' beat, Scottish [[Folk music|folk]]-inspired tunes, kids-style '[[Mickey Mouse]]' scoring, martial music, light [[jazz]], and light [[Classical music|classical]]",<ref name="Allmusic" /> and singles out both "Cocktail Music", from "[[Model Spy]]", and the piano track, performed by Gray, from "[[The Inquisition (Captain Scarlet)|The Inquisition]]", for particular praise.<ref name="Allmusic" /> In his [[BBC Online]] review, Peter Marsh opines that the darker tone of the music is reflective of ''Captain Scarlet'' as a programme featuring realistic puppets and death,<ref name="BBCReview" /> frightening alien villains<ref name="BBCReview" /> and "no laughs",<ref name="BBCReview" /> stating that "dissonant [[vibraphone]] chords shimmer under hovering, tremulous strings contrasted with urgent, [[militaristic]] drums and pulsing brass – driving the action ever onto its climax (and, no doubt, a big explosion)."<ref name="BBCReview" />
In October 2015, [[Fanderson]] released a 3-disc set exclusively for club members. It contains music either written for, or used in, all but three episodes ("[[The Heart of New York (Captain Scarlet)|The Heart of New York]]" and "[[Treble Cross]]" contain no original music and the cue recordings for "[[Traitor (Captain Scarlet)|Traitor]]" are lost).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fanderson.org.uk/gerryandersonnews/2015/09/captain-scarlet-soundtrack-cd-now-on-sale/|title=''Captain Scarlet'' Soundtrack CD Now On Sale!|date=27 September 2015|work=fanderson.org.uk|publisher=[[Fanderson]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151112175719/http://fanderson.org.uk/gerryandersonnews/2015/09/captain-scarlet-soundtrack-cd-now-on-sale/|archivedate=12 November 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=12 November 2015}}</ref>
