==Puppets== {{See also|Supermarionation}} [[File:CaptainScarletPuppets.ogg|thumb|thumbtime=30|250px|Changes made to the original [[Supermarionation]] design made puppet motion more stilted than before.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 203" /> To portray a walk, an operator would need to hold the puppet's legs, while the camera maintained a [[close-up]] shot to conceal the hand from view.<ref name="Bentley, 16" /> This clip from the episode "[[Attack on Cloudbase]]" has an interruption in the shot when the characters of Captains [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Scarlet]] and [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Blue]] are required to step through a door into the [[Cloudbase]] Radar Room to talk to Captain Magenta, since the strings supporting the puppet heads made it impossible to film such entrances in a continuous shot.<ref name="HowsWhys" /> Through the characters of Scarlet and [[Colonel White]], whose English accents are demonstrated, Marcus Hearn and Simon Archer argue that the impression that ''Captain Scarlet'' leaves on viewers differs from that of ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]''.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 169" />|alt=Video clip from "Attack on Cloudbase" demonstrating the difficulties of inducing realistic motion in the puppet characters of "Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons". Whenever a character is required to move, the camera shifts to a close-up angle to conceal the hand of a puppeteer pushing the puppet forward. The shot is interrupted when Captains Scarlet and Blue walk into a room through an automatic door as it was impossible to film the action in a single motion.]]
Supermarionation, a technique in which the movement of the [[marionette]] puppet's mouth is electronically [[Lip sync|synchronised]] with character dialogue, had been formulated by [[Gerry Anderson]] for ''[[Four Feather Falls]]'' in 1960. Until production for ''Captain Scarlet'', the head of the puppet had been disproportionately large in comparison to its body, as the head contained a [[solenoid]] that formed the key component of the lip-synch mechanism. The production team was not able to scale up the body to match the head, as this would have made the puppets hard to operate<ref name="ToonhoundEntry">{{cite web|title= Captain Scarlet |url= http://www.toonhound.com/captainscarlet.htm|work=toonhound.com|accessdate=26 November 2009|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080503021338/http://www.toonhound.com/captainscarlet.htm|archivedate=3 May 2008| deadurl =no}}</ref> and have necessitated a proportionate scaling-up in the size of the puppet sets.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 151">Archer and Hearn, p. 151.</ref> Since Gerry Anderson had expressed frustration with this [[caricature]]d design during the production of earlier Supermarionation series, and wished that the puppets would more accurately reflect human biology,<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 151" /> before production commenced on ''Captain Scarlet'' the producer, [[Reg Hill]], and his associate, [[John Read (producer)|John Read]],<ref name = "Drake and Bassett, 203">Drake and Bassett, p. 203.</ref> designed a new type of puppet in which the solenoid was instead placed inside the chest, to permit a head of realistic proportion.<ref name="HowsWhys" /><ref name = "TVHeaven" /><ref name = "ToonhoundEntry" /><ref name="Puppets">{{cite web |last=Wickes |first=Simon |title=FAQ – Puppets |url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=112:the-puppets-look-different-between-thunderbirds-and-captain-scarlet-what-happened&catid=122:faqs&Itemid=179 |work=tvcentury21.com |date=2 January 2004 |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m00k9kSq?url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=112:the-puppets-look-different-between-thunderbirds-and-captain-scarlet-what-happened&catid=122:faqs&Itemid=179 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The [[costume designer]] for ''Captain Scarlet'' was [[Sylvia Anderson]], who was influenced by the work of French fashion designer [[Pierre Cardin]], in particular his 1966 "Cosmonaut" collection, in designing the Spectrum uniforms.<ref name="Bentley, 19">Bentley 2001, p. 19.</ref>
After test-sculpting in [[Plasticine]], the puppet heads were moulded on a [[silicone rubber]] base and made using [[fibreglass]]. At heights ranging from 20 to 24 inches (approximately one-third life-size) the next-generation puppets were no shorter than their predecessors.<ref name="Bentley, 18">Bentley 2001, p. 18.</ref> For previous series, puppet eyes had been sized out of proportion to the heads, but as part of the realistic look introduced in ''Captain Scarlet'', the eyes of production personnel were photographed and the images scaled down for attachment to the eye sockets.<ref name = "HowsWhys" /><ref name = "Teletronic" /><ref name = "Archer, 55">Archer, p. 55.</ref> As had been the case for earlier series, a number of alternative heads displaying a range of expressions were created for main character puppets, including "smilers", "frowners" and "blinkers".<ref name="Bentley, 18" /> Since episodes of ''Captain Scarlet'' were filmed in pairs, one on each of the puppet stages available at the [[AP Films#Century21|Century 21]] Studios, duplicates were made of the "expressionless" template of each main character.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 266">Drake and Bassett, p. 266.</ref> For the [[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|first episode]], an "agony" head was specially sculpted for the [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]] puppet for a brief [[reaction shot]] of Scarlet's [[Mysteron]] double being shot by [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Blue]].
The increased [[Realism (arts)|realism]] of the puppets meant that their mobility was significantly reduced,<ref name = "HowsWhys" /> ironically leaving the new design less lifelike than Anderson had hoped,<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 203" /> as he recalls: "Suddenly, all the movements had to be as realistic as the puppets and that made it difficult for the puppeteers to animate them."<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 203" /> To minimise the amount of movement required, the puppets were made to stand on moving walkways or sit at moving desks: for example, [[Colonel White]]'s desk on [[Cloudbase]] is seen to rotate, while [[Lieutenant Green]] is seen to operate the Cloudbase main computer from a sliding chair. Puppeteer Jan King recalls:
{{Quote|The ''Captain Scarlet'' puppets were not built to walk. They were too heavy and not weighted properly anyway ... It is virtually impossible to get a string puppet to walk convincingly on film unless it is a very caricatured puppet. In ''Captain Scarlet'', if a puppet had to move off-screen, it was done in a [[Medium shot|head-and-shoulders shot]] – the floor puppeteer would hold the legs of the puppet and then move the puppet physically out of shot at the right time, trying to make the body and shoulders move as if the puppet were walking.<ref name = "Bentley, 16">Bentley 2001, p. 16.</ref>}}
The "under control" puppets described by King were stringless and controlled from the waist. One resulting advantage was that a puppet could be moved through a doorway without necessitating a break in the shot. For shots displaying characters such as the Angels seated in aircraft cockpits, variations of the "under control" design, comprising just a head and torso, were manipulated by levers and wires positioned underneath the set.<ref name="HowsWhys" /> This development of Supermarionation would be named "[[Supermarionation#Supermacromation|Supermacromation]]" when Anderson returned to puppetry in the 1980s with his later production, ''[[Terrahawks]]''.
===Revamp puppets and likenesses=== {{Quote box|quote=I still wonder about the wisdom of our decision to change the puppets. The heads were reduced in size to make them in proportion with the rest of their bodies, but the problem was that exact and precise movements became more vital than ever and that caused us terrible difficulties. After creating [[Snow White (Disney character)|Snow White]] in perfect human form, [[Walt Disney]] said he'd never repeat that mistake, and I still have doubts about whether or not we did the right thing.|salign=right|source=– [[Gerry Anderson]] (2001)<ref name="Bentley, 14" />|width=20%}}
Before ''Captain Scarlet'', supporting character puppets had been specially sculpted in [[clay]] as and when episodes required them. The guest parts in ''Captain Scarlet'', however, were filled by a permanent "repertory company" of over 50 puppets made to the same standards of workmanship as the main characters.<ref name="ToonhoundEntry" /><ref name = "Bentley, 18" /> Known as "revamp puppets" or "revamps", these puppets appeared on an episode-by-episode basis, cosmetically altered for each role in aspects such as hairstyle and hair colour.<ref name="HowsWhys" /><ref name="ToonhoundEntry" /><ref name="Bentley, 18" /> An initial intention was for each episode to include a "guest star" puppet to be sculpted on, and voiced by, a known public figure but this idea was abandoned due to budgetary constraints.<ref name="HowsWhys" /><ref name="Drake and Bassett, 203" /> Both main character and revamp puppets from ''Captain Scarlet'' appeared in Anderson's final two [[Supermarionation]] series, ''[[Joe 90]]'' and ''[[The Secret Service]]''.<ref name="ToonhoundEntry" />
The likeness of the [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]] character has, since his first appearance, been attributed to [[Francis Matthews (actor)|Francis Matthews]],<ref name="Likenesses">{{cite web |last=Wickes |first=Simon |title=FAQ – Voices and Likenesses |url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=117:captain-scarlets-voice-sounds-just-like-cary-grant-intentional&catid=122:faqs&Itemid=179 |work=tvcentury21.com |date=2 January 2004 |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m00rQp77?url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=117:captain-scarlets-voice-sounds-just-like-cary-grant-intentional&catid=122:faqs&Itemid=179 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> who voiced Scarlet in the series, [[Cary Grant]]<ref name="Likenesses" /> and [[Roger Moore]].<ref name="Likenesses" /><ref name="Archer, 86">Archer, p. 86.</ref> [[Ed Bishop]] later claimed that [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Blue]] had been modelled on his likeness,<ref name="Bentley, 17" /> but sculptor Terry Curtis states that he made the puppet to resemble himself and simply added a blond wig when he learnt that Bishop was to voice Blue.<ref name="Bentley, 17" /> Curtis, a [[James Bond]] fan,<ref name="Bentley, 16" /> based the appearance of Captain Grey on [[Sean Connery]]<ref name="Bentley, 16" /><ref name="Cull: Media History, 206">Cull 2006 (August), p. 206.</ref> and Destiny Angel on [[Ursula Andress]],<ref name="Bentley, 17" /><ref name="Archer, 81">Archer, p. 81.</ref> Connery's co-star in the 1962 Bond film ''[[Dr. No (film)|Dr No]]''. Meanwhile, the character of [[Lieutenant Green]] was sculpted on its voice actor, [[Cy Grant]];<ref name="Bentley, 17" /> Rhapsody Angel on model and actress [[Jean Shrimpton]];<ref name="Archer, 88">Archer, p. 88.</ref> Melody Angel on singer and actress [[Eartha Kitt]];<ref name="Archer, 86" /> and Harmony Angel on actress [[Tsai Chin (actress)|Tsai Chin]].<ref name="Archer, 93">Archer, p. 93.</ref> {{Clear}}
==Casting and characters== {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-right: 0; margin-left: 1em;" |+ Regular Puppet Cast |- !Codename||Real name<ref group="n" name="RealDebated">No real names, except those of Scarlet and [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Blue]], are used in the television episodes. Instead, they originate from licensed associated media, such as Bentley's ''The Complete Book of Captain Scarlet''.</ref><ref name="RealNames">All real names and nationalities in the voice cast list originate from the character biographies in ''The Complete Book of Captain Scarlet'' (2001), by Chris Bentley, pp. 44–51.</ref>||Nationality<ref name="RealNames" />||Voice actor(s) |- |[[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]]||Paul Metcalfe||British||[[Francis Matthews (actor)|Francis Matthews]] |- |[[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Blue]]||Adam Svenson||American||[[Ed Bishop]] |- |[[Colonel White]]||Charles Gray||British||[[Donald Gray]] |- |[[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]]||Conrad Turner||British||Donald Gray<ref group="n" name="CapBlackVoice">In "The Mysterons" and a flashback sequence in "Dangerous Rendezvous", Captain Black's human voice is provided by [[Jeremy Wilkin]].</ref> |- |[[Lieutenant Green]]||Seymour Griffiths||Trinidadian||[[Cy Grant]] |- |Captain Ochre||Richard Fraser||American||[[Jeremy Wilkin]] |- |Captain Magenta||Patrick Donaghue||Irish||[[Gary Files]] |- |Captain Grey||Bradley Holden||American||[[Paul Maxwell]] |- |Doctor Fawn||Edward Wilkie||Australian||[[Charles Tingwell]] |- |Destiny Angel||Juliette Pontoin||French||[[Elizabeth Morgan (actress)|Liz Morgan]] |- |Symphony Angel||Karen Wainwright||American||Janna Hill |- |Rhapsody Angel||Dianne Simms||British||Liz Morgan |- |Melody Angel||Magnolia Jones||American||[[Sylvia Anderson]] |- |Harmony Angel||Chan Kwan||Chinese||Liz Morgan <br /> Lian-Shin |}
The regular puppet cast of ''Captain Scarlet'' was the largest of all the Anderson [[Supermarionation]] series.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 232">Drake and Bassett, p. 232.</ref> While earlier productions had emphasised the benefits of futuristic technology,<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 232" /> for ''Captain Scarlet'' it was decided to develop and deepen the cast of characters.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 232" /> Further to the enhanced [[Realism (arts)|realism]] of the puppet design, voice roles for ''Captain Scarlet'' were, as opposed to ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' and other predecessors, also intended to be less [[caricature]]d.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 240">Drake and Bassett, p. 240.</ref> Anderson biographers Simon Archer and Marcus Hearn note that, between ''Thunderbirds'' and ''Captain Scarlet,'' a proliferation of English-accented voices altered the sound of the Supermarionation production and its impression on the viewer.<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 169">Archer and Hearn, p. 169.</ref>
[[Francis Matthews (actor)|Francis Matthews]], voicing [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]], had previously turned down offers for voice-acting on ''Thunderbirds''.<ref name="Bentley, 23">Bentley 2001, p. 23.</ref> Matthews claims that [[Gerry Anderson]] went to great lengths to get him to sign on to ''Captain Scarlet'' because of the skilled [[Cary Grant]] impression that he had once used for a radio programme,<ref name="Bentley, 23" /><ref name="Newmark">{{cite news|last=Newmark |first=Russell |title=Outside Edge: Mysterons Beware |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/outside-edge-mysterons-beware-1507965.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |location=London |date=1 October 1993 |accessdate=22 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m0240aBP?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/outside-edge-mysterons-beware-1507965.html |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> and indeed the English actor based the tones of Scarlet on Grant's [[Mid-Atlantic English|Mid-Atlantic]] accent.<ref name="Archer, 43">Archer, p. 43.</ref> In contrast, Anderson claims in his biography<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 153">Archer and Hearn, p. 153.</ref> that the impression was Matthews's choice at audition, and that whilst it was not what had been intended for Captain Scarlet, the production team nevertheless elected to use it.<ref name="TVHeaven" /><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 153" /> Matthews's filmography prior to ''Captain Scarlet'' included the [[Hammer Film Productions|Hammer]] films ''[[The Revenge of Frankenstein]]'' (1958), ''[[Rasputin, the Mad Monk]]'' (1966) and ''[[Dracula: Prince of Darkness]]'' (1966).
Matthews's co-star in ''Dracula: Prince of Darkness'' had been [[Charles Tingwell]], who was chosen to voice Doctor Fawn, the [[Cloudbase]] chief medical officer. Tingwell, who had provided voices for the second season of ''Thunderbirds'' and its first feature film, ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go]]'', had initially been recommended to the Andersons by [[Ray Barrett]],<ref name="Bentley, 29">Bentley 2001, p. 29.</ref> a fellow Australian actor who had worked on ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]'' and ''Thunderbirds''. However, due to commitments to a touring theatre production, Tingwell could only contribute to the first twelve produced episodes of ''Captain Scarlet'', ending with "[[Shadow of Fear]]".<ref name="Bentley, 29" /> Also departing after the completion of "Shadow of Fear" was the voice of Captain Grey, [[Paul Maxwell]],<ref name="Bentley, 29" /> a Canadian actor who had voiced the characters of Steve Zodiac and Captain Paul Travers in ''[[Fireball XL5]]'' and ''Thunderbirds Are Go'' respectively, who dropped out of production due to being cast as [[List of Coronation Street characters (1967)#Steve Tanner|Steve Tanner]] in ''[[Coronation Street]]''.<ref name="Bentley, 29" /> As a result, Doctor Fawn and Captain Grey appeared in the remainder of the series in a non-speaking capacity only, although other characters voiced by Tingwell and Maxwell occasionally appeared in flashback sequences of specific episodes.
[[Cy Grant]], a Guyanese actor selected for the role of [[Lieutenant Green]]<ref group="n" name="Leftenant">"Lieutenant" is generally pronounced in the British manner, {{IPAc-en|l|ɛ|f|ˈ|t|ɛ|n|ə|n|t}} {{respell|lef|TEN|ənt}}, by all but the American characters in the series.</ref> (Colonel White's assistant and Cloudbase's main [[computer operator]] and [[Public address|public announcer]]), had been known to the Andersons for singing topical [[Calypso music|calypsos]] on the current affairs programme ''[[Tonight (1957 TV series)|Tonight]]''.<ref name="CGWeb">{{cite web|last=Grant|first=Cy|authorlink=Cy Grant|title=Lieutenant Green and De Anderson CODE – Spectrums, Subconscious Connections & Synchronicities|url=http://nestene1.users.btopenworld.com/cygrant/green.html|work=cygrant.com|year=2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123195856/http://nestene1.users.btopenworld.com/cygrant/green.html|archivedate=23 January 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> His casting influenced the decision to accept [[Ed Bishop|Edward Bishop]] as [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Blue]] (Captain Scarlet's friend and mission partner),<ref name="Starlog">{{cite journal|last=Hirsh|first=David|date=February 1982|title=''Starlog'' Exclusive: Commander Straker Speaks! An Interview with Ed Bishop|journal=[[Starlog]]|issue=55|publisher=Starlog Group|issn=0191-4626|oclc=474082490|url=http://ufoseries.com/magazines/starlog55.html|accessdate=17 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225010532/http://ufoseries.com/magazines/starlog55.html|archivedate=25 February 2008|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="MJSimpson">{{cite web|title=Ed Bishop Interview|url=http://www.mjsimpson.co.uk/interviews/edbishopa.html|work=mjsimpson.co.uk|accessdate=2 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029014902/http://www.mjsimpson.co.uk/interviews/edbishopa.html|archivedate=29 October 2007|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> as Bishop recalled in an interview recorded in 1995: "It was just that a girl in my agent's office happened to be on the ball. She represented this black actor by the name of Cy Grant and Gerry and [[Sylvia Anderson|Sylvia]] wanted to use him ... And the girl said, 'Oh, by the way, Mr Anderson, we've just taken on a new, young American actor' – shows you how long ago it was – 'a new American actor, name of Edward Bishop. And we know how much you like American voices. Would you like to meet him as well?' He said, 'Okay, send him out.' So I went out and auditioned and got the job."<ref name="MJSimpson" />
[[Donald Gray]], who had found himself [[Typecasting (acting)|typecast]] after appearing in the lead role in ''[[Saber of London]]'', a [[Detective fiction|detective series]], was having to resort to voice work to support his acting career.<ref name="Bentley, 25">Bentley 2001, p. 25.</ref> The South African actor was selected for three regular roles: [[Colonel White]], [[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]] and the [[Mysteron]]s. After his mind is hijacked in the [[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|first episode]], Black speaks with the same voice that the Mysterons are heard to use when transmitting threats to [[Earth]]. For his portrayals of Black and his Mysteron masters, Gray's voice was electronically deepened, by running the tape at high speed whilst he was recording his lines and playing it back at normal speed, to produce a haunting effect.
The voice of Captain Ochre was provided by English-born Canadian, [[Jeremy Wilkin]]. Having served in the role of [[Virgil Tracy]] during the second series of ''Thunderbirds,'' Wilkin remained to voice Ochre for the subsequent production. The character of Captain Magenta, meanwhile, was voiced by [[Gary Files]]. Another Australian actor, Files was a fresh addition to [[AP Films#Century 21|Century 21 Productions]], and was cast for a number of roles in the second ''Thunderbirds'' film, ''[[Thunderbird 6]],'' before progressing to the role of Magenta for ''Captain Scarlet.''<ref name="GFInterview">{{cite web|title=Gary Files Interview |url=http://www.thevervoid.com/media/scarlet_interview.htm |work=thevervoid.com |accessdate=3 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626072515/http://www.thevervoid.com/media/scarlet_interview.htm |archivedate=26 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Like Files, Welsh actress [[Elizabeth Morgan (actor)|Liz Morgan]] was new to the Anderson productions and voiced the regular characters of Destiny Angel, the lead pilot of the Spectrum Angel fighter squadron, and one of her subordinates, Rhapsody Angel.
[[Sylvia Anderson]], the voice of [[Lady Penelope]] from ''Thunderbirds,'' voiced Melody Angel, while Canadian actress Janna Hill was given the part of Symphony. The character of Harmony Angel was voiced by Morgan for five episodes before being replaced by Chinese actress Lian-Shin<ref name="Bentley, 27">Bentley 2001, p. 27.</ref><ref name="LMInterview">{{cite web |title=Liz Morgan: Interviews |url=http://www.amb-cotedazur.com/Interviews/liz-morgan.html |work=amb-cotedazur.com |date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m01uRyxG?url=http://www.amb-cotedazur.com/Interviews/liz-morgan.html |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> about one-third of the way through the recording sessions.<ref name="La Rivière, 159">La Rivière, p. 159.</ref> Although Lian provided the voice of Harmony for only one episode, "[[The Launching]],"<ref name="La Rivière, 159" /> she received billing for 20 episodes.<ref name="La Rivière, 159" />
Supporting character voices were performed by Anderson, Files, Hill, Maxwell, Morgan, Tingwell and Wilkin. Completing the supporting cast were American actor [[David Healy (actor)|David Healy]] and British actor [[Martin King (actor)|Martin King]]. Canadian [[Shane Rimmer]], who had performed the voice of [[Scott Tracy]] in ''Thunderbirds'' and its films, made a number of uncredited contributions in addition to writing for the series. Fellow Canadian [[Neil McCallum (actor)|Neil McCallum]], who had provided the voice of the character of Dr Ray Pierce in ''Thunderbirds Are Go'', can be heard in four episodes, though he was not credited. Gerry Anderson himself lent his voice to the episode "[[Lunarville 7]]"; he too went uncredited.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 59">Drake and Bassett, p. 59.</ref> Six members of the voice cast would continue their association with the Andersons after ''Captain Scarlet''. Healy would voice the character of Shane Weston in the penultimate Supermarionation series, ''[[Joe 90]]'', while Files would voice Matthew Harding on ''[[The Secret Service]]''. Wilkin, Morgan and King were all given small roles for these final two Supermarionation series, while Bishop appeared as SHADO Commander Edward Straker in Anderson's live-action series, ''[[UFO (TV series)|UFO]]'', which was transmitted in the United Kingdom from 1970.
===Voice recording=== Character dialogue was recorded on a fortnightly basis,<ref name="Bentley, 41" /> with lines for up to four episodes taped at each session,<ref name="Bentley, 30">Bentley 2001, p. 30.</ref> at the [[Denham Film Studios|Anvil Films Recording Studio]]<ref group="l" name="Denham">[[Denham Film Studios|Anvil Films Recording Studio]]: {{Coord|51.5632|-0.4987|type:landmark_region:GB-NWP|name=Anvil Films Recording Studio, Denham, Buckinghamshire|format=dms}} (voice recording)</ref> at [[Denham, Buckinghamshire|Denham]] in [[Buckinghamshire]].<ref name="Bentley, 30" /> Each actor, regardless of the size of their contribution, was paid 15 guineas (£15 15 shillings) per episode<ref name="Bentley, 24">Bentley 2001, p. 24.</ref> with repeat fees.<ref name="Bentley, 24" /> The cast were not given the opportunity to tour the [[AP Films#Century 21|Century 21]] studios in [[Slough]] until all their work was finished<ref name="Bentley, 23" /> and therefore had no visualisation of their characters during the recording itself. This was to the regret of [[Elizabeth Morgan (actress)|Liz Morgan]]: "We all said that we wished we had seen the puppets before doing the dialogue, as it would have been helpful to have something physical to base the voices on. I knew that Destiny was French and that Rhapsody had to be frightfully '[[Sloane Ranger|Sloaney]],' but that was about it."<ref name="Bentley, 27" />
==Titles and credits== [[File:Spectrum Organisation (Captain Scarlett) logo.png|thumb|The Spectrum logo, designed by Tony Dunsterville, appears at both the start and the end of an episode's midpoint [[Television advertisement|advertisement break]].]]
All ''Captain Scarlet'' episodes, except the first, incorporate two sets of [[opening titles]]. The first of these sequences displays the [[title card]] and the primary production credits. The camera moves forward through the scale-model set of a run-down, night-time alleyway, forming the [[Point of view shot|point-of-view shot]] of an unseen assassin, who turns a corner only to meet his death at the gun barrel of [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]]. The two seven-letter words "Captain Scarlet" gradually appear in time with the seven strikes of the ''Captain Scarlet'' staccato drum beat composed by [[Barry Gray]]. This opening sequence is accompanied by a [[voice-over]] from [[Ed Bishop]], which states:
{{quote|"The Mysterons. Sworn enemies of Earth. Possessing the ability to recreate an exact likeness of an object or person. But first, they must destroy. Leading the fight: one man fate has made indestructible. His name: Captain Scarlet."}}
The sequence is intended to demonstrate Captain Scarlet's indestructibility, with the assassin's machine-gun bullets having no apparent effect on their target.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 244">Drake and Bassett, p. 244.</ref>
A number of variations of the voice-over have been used. Bishop's introduction to the pilot, which is unique to that episode, runs:<ref group="e" name="The Mysterons" />
{{quote|"The finger is on the trigger. About to unleash a force with terrible powers, beyond the comprehension of man. This force we shall know as: the Mysterons. This man will be our hero, for fate will make him indestructible. His name: Captain Scarlet."}}
A little-used alternative version runs:<ref name="Lesterdemon">{{cite journal|last1=Pixley |first1=Andrew |author2=Michael Richardson, Alice Hendry |year=1985 |title=Supermarionation – the UK Broadcasts |journal=Supermarionation is Go! |issue=14–5 |publisher=Super M Productions |url=http://lester.demon.nl/superm/broadcastsUK.html |accessdate=6 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m02NT3pI?url=http://lester.demon.nl/superm/broadcastsUK.html |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
{{quote|"One man. A man who is different. Chosen by fate. Caught up in Earth's unwanted conflict with the Mysterons. Determined. Courageous. Indestructible. His name: Captain Scarlet."}}
Later [[Release print|prints]] feature an additional voice-over by [[Donald Gray]], warning:<ref name="Lesterdemon" /><ref name="La Rivière, 163">La Rivière, p. 163.</ref>
{{quote|"Captain Scarlet is indestructible. You are not. Remember this. Do not try to imitate him."}}
This served both to establish the background to the series and to warn child viewers not to risk their safety by copying Scarlet's actions.<ref name="Lesterdemon" /><ref name="Cull: Media History, 200">Cull 2006 (August), p. 200.</ref> It was either placed after the alternative "One man ..." voice-over<ref name="Lesterdemon" /> or used in isolation, such that no voice-over by Bishop was heard.<ref name="Lesterdemon" />
From the [[Winged Assassin|second episode]] onwards, a secondary opening sequence runs immediately after an initial [[Cold open|teaser]]: as the Mysterons announce their latest threat against Earth, the "Mysteron rings" pass over the primary puppet cast in a number of environments to demonstrate the aliens' omnipresence.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 244" /> Meanwhile, the characters's Spectrum code names are flashed up on-screen. The Mysterons invariably begin their threat with the words, "This is the voice of the Mysterons. We know that you can hear us, [[Earthling|Earthmen]]."
{{Quote box|quote=The [[Opening titles|titles]] on the series were always devised by me. When it came to ''Scarlet'' I was frightened people would say, 'Oh, it's the same old "crash, bang, wallop" stuff again.' So I made a conscious effort to do something totally different. I don't think I necessarily did the right thing.|salign=right|source=– [[Gerry Anderson]] (2001)<ref name="Teletronic" /><ref name="TVHeaven" />|width=21%|align=left}}
The [[end credits]] sequence was originally intended to feature images of [[printed circuit board]]s and other electronic components, to reflect the Andersons's early conception of the resurrected Captain Scarlet as being a "[[Android (robot)|mechanical man]]."<ref name="Bentley, 15" /> In the completed sequence, the end production credits are superimposed on a series of ten paintings, which depict Scarlet in moments of extreme danger. In earlier episodes, these images are accompanied by the instrumental version of Barry Gray's ''Captain Scarlet'' theme music; in later ones, this is replaced by the lyrical version sung by The Spectrum. The paintings were produced by comic artist [[Ron Embleton]], who would later illustrate the adult comic strips ''[[Wicked Wanda|Oh, Wicked Wanda!]]'' and ''Sweet Chastity'' for ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]]'' Magazine.<ref name="Bentley, 102">Bentley 2001, p. 102.</ref><ref name="Prints">{{cite web |last=Wickes |first=Simon |title=Prints of ''Scarlet'' End Titles Available |url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=317:prints-of-scarlet-end-titles-available&catid=71:miscellaneous&Itemid=178 |work=tvcentury21.com |date=6 June 2005 |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m02CWUql?url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=317:prints-of-scarlet-end-titles-available&catid=71:miscellaneous&Itemid=178 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In 2005, the Animation Art Gallery in London released licensed limited editions of the paintings signed by [[Francis Matthews (actor)|Francis Matthews]], who had provided the voice of Captain Scarlet.<ref name="Prints" /><ref name="BBCArt">{{cite web|title=''Scarlet'' Art |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/news/cult/2005/02/11/16980.shtml |work=[[BBC Online]] |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=11 February 2005 |accessdate=6 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m02GyRcC?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/news/cult/2005/02/11/16980.shtml |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
In Japan, the original opening credit sequences were replaced with a montage of action clips from various episodes, accompanied by a unique [[theme song]] performed by children. This version is included in the special features of the ''Captain Scarlet'' DVD box set.<ref name="SHJapanese">{{cite web|last=Bishop |first=Chris |title=Japanese Names as Used in ''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons'' |url=http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/japanese_names.htm |work=spectrum-headquarters.com |date=13 February 2008 |accessdate=6 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m02gMbFO?url=http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/japanese_names.htm |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="SHDVD">{{cite web|last=Bishop|first=Chris|title=Merchandising – Multimedias: DVD|url=http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/DVDpage.html|work=spectrum-headquarters.com|date=21 February 2006|accessdate=22 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080510221055/http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/DVDpage.html|archivedate=10 May 2008|deadurl=no}}</ref> {{Clear}}
==Broadcasts== ''Captain Scarlet'' officially opened on British television on 29 September 1967, in the late-afternoon slot of 5.25 pm, in the [[ATV Midlands]] region. [[Audience measurement|Viewing figures]] for the first episode, "[[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|The Mysterons]]", were promising at 0.45 million.<ref name="Bentley, 118">Bentley 2001, p. 118.</ref> Five months earlier, on 29 April, the series opener had been given a late-night test transmission in the London area.<ref name="Bentley, 118" /> After the start of the [[English Midlands|Midlands]] broadcasts, London and Scotland followed on 1 October,<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 207">Drake and Bassett, p. 207.</ref> with the [[Granada Television|Granada]], [[Anglia Television|Anglia]], [[Southern Television|Southern]], [[Westward Television|Westward]] and [[Channel Television|Channel]] areas all televising the series by the end of the month.<ref name="Bentley, 118" /> However, it was not until the start of 1968 that the series was being broadcast all across the nation.<ref name="Bentley, 118" /> In the Midlands region, the ratings averaged 1.1 million.<ref name="Bentley, 118" /> In 1968, ''Captain Scarlet'' was also screened in more than 40 other countries, including Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan.<ref name="Bentley, 119">Bentley 2001, p. 119.</ref> In the United States, the series was transmitted on [[Broadcast syndication#First-run syndication in the U.S.|first-run syndication]].<ref name="CrimeTV" /><ref name="scifiontv">{{cite web |title=Sci-Fi on TV: Archive List |url=http://www.scifiontv.com/archive_list.php |work=scifiontv.com |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m02nqQFP?url=http://www.scifiontv.com/archive_list.php |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Meanwhile, only six episodes of the series were transmitted in the Netherlands.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 282">Drake and Bassett, p. 282.</ref>
[[Rerun|Repeat runs]] have varied greatly according to region. While Granada, [[ITV Wales & West|HTV]] and [[ITV Tyne Tees|Tyne Tees]] continued to broadcast the series into 1972,<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 283">Drake and Bassett, p. 283.</ref> the Midlands received four [[Color television|colour]] re-runs from 1969 to 1974,<ref name="Bentley, 119" /> while in other areas, such as [[Yorkshire]], it was not repeated at all.<ref name="Bentley, 119" /> All 32 episodes were purchased by [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] for broadcast on Saturday mornings between 1985 and 1986,<ref name="Bentley, 119" /><ref name="Drake and Bassett, 286">Drake and Bassett, p. 286.</ref> with broadcasting in segmented form on the ITV [[Night Network]] in 1987.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 286" /> A BBC commission led to the series' first simultaneous [[Television network|network]] broadcast on [[BBC2]] starting on 1 October 1993.<ref name="Bentley, 122">Bentley 2001, p. 122.</ref> On this occasion, the first episode attracted an audience of four million,<ref name="Bentley, 122" /> high enough to award it third position in the BBC2 ratings chart for the week of transmission.<ref name="Bentley, 122" />
[[Remaster|Digitally remastered]], the series resurfaced on BBC Two in the autumn of 2001.<ref name="Bentley, 125">Bentley 2001, p. 125.</ref> On this occasion, the episode schedule needed to be re-arranged at short notice to avoid offence in the immediate [[aftermath of the September 11 attacks]].<ref name="ToonhoundEntry" /> The second episode, "[[Winged Assassin]]", in which the [[Mysteron]]s destroy and reconstruct a plane to assassinate a world leader, and the third, "[[Big Ben Strikes Again]]", in which London comes under threat from an atomic device, were held back and replaced with the fourth episode, "[[Manhunt (Captain Scarlet)|Manhunt]]", due to parallels between the plotlines and events in the real world.<ref name="THound01">{{cite web|url=http://www.toonhound.com/oct2001.htm|title=The Hound – October 2001: ''Scarlet'' Faces ... |work=toonhound.com|date=October 2001|accessdate=26 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409102053/http://www.toonhound.com/oct2001.htm|archivedate=9 April 2008|deadurl=no}}</ref> In the week after the attacks, the ''Captain Scarlet'' section on the [[Carlton Communications|Carlton]] website was also temporarily removed.<ref name="THound01" />
==Reception== {{Quote box|quote=''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons'' should have been one of the most successful puppet shows and it wasn't. I think it was too perfect. There was a lack of humour. It was too mechanical and needed humanising ... [Gerry] always wanted to make the characters a lot more rigid than I did. I wanted to start to give them human flaws, start to make them more important. He was more inclined to make them just say the lines and fit into a rigid pattern, but if you don't care about the characters, it doesn't really work.|salign=right|source=– [[Sylvia Anderson]] (1992)<ref name="SAInterview">{{cite web|last=Turner |first=Stephen |title=Sylvia Anderson Interview (1992) |url=http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=63:sylvia-anderson-interview-1992&catid=115:production-staff&Itemid=182 |work=tvcentury21.com |date=25 December 2003 |accessdate=3 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717115240/http://www.tvcentury21.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=63%3Asylvia-anderson-interview-1992&catid=115%3Aproduction-staff&Itemid=182 |archivedate=17 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>|width=20%|align=right}}
While ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' had run for two series, [[Lew Grade]]'s unexpected cancellation of the production led Anderson to assume that there was no possibility of ''Captain Scarlet'' lasting for more than one.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 280">Drake and Bassett, p. 280.</ref> In Anderson's words, "I didn't expect it to continue. I simply went to Lew and asked, 'What's the next thing you want us to do?{{'"}}<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 166">Archer and Hearn, p. 166.</ref>
''Captain Scarlet'' has generally been viewed as much "darker"<ref name="Cambridge">{{cite book|last1=Bould|first1=Mark|editor1-last=James|editor1-first=Edward|editor2-last=Mendlesohn|editor2-first=Farah|editor2-link=Farah Mendlesohn|title=The Cambridge Companion to Science Fiction|chapter=Film and Television|year=2003|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=978-0-521-01657-5|page=90}}</ref><ref name="TVHeaven" /> in tone compared to Gerry Anderson's earlier science-fiction programmes, as Andrew Billen noted in ''[[New Statesman]]'' when its remake was broadcast 2005: "Whereas ''Thunderbirds'' was about rescuing people, ''Scarlet'' was about damnation, the soul of a resurrected man being fought for between [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Captain Scarlet]] and the equally indestructible [[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]]. It was Anderson's [[Gothic fiction|Gothic]] period."<ref name="NewStatesman">{{cite journal|last=Billen |first=Andrew |title=Red-Hot Hero |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200502210044 |journal=[[New Statesman]] |publisher=Spencer Neal |location=London |issn=1364-7431 |oclc=35012871 |date=21 February 2005 |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m02uMAOq?url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200502210044 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> The horror factor of the [[Mysteron]]s has been recognised, with the depiction of the extraterrestrials giving the series a ranking of 82nd in [[Channel 4]]'s 2003 list programme ''100 Greatest Scary Moments''.<ref name="100Scary">{{cite web|title=''100 Greatest Scary Moments'': Channel 4 Film|url=http://www.channel4.com/film/newsfeatures/microsites/S/scary/results_90-81_2.html|work=[[channel4.com]]|publisher=Channel 4|year=2003|accessdate=1 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625050328/http://www.channel4.com/film/newsfeatures/microsites/S/scary/results_90-81_2.html|archivedate=25 June 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Simon Wickes of the TV Century 21 website asserts that serious writing of the scripts is ultimately due to the [[Realism (arts)|realism]] of the new, accurately-proportioned puppets, and that this aesthetic change also answers for the heightened realism of the series' [[scale model]]s.<ref name="HowsWhys" />
Parallels have been drawn between ''Captain Scarlet'' and the [[Cold War]].<ref name="BritishCulture">{{cite book|last=Christopher|first=David|title=British Culture: an Introduction|publisher=[[Routledge]]|location=London|year=1999|page=114|isbn=978-0-415-22053-8|chapter=Television and Radio}}</ref> Historian [[Nicholas J. Cull]] interprets the "war of nerves" between [[Earth]] and [[Mars]] as a reflection of the strain on international relations during the 1960s and likens the "enemy within" scenario of Martians taking physical control of humans to the plots of such films as ''[[Invasion of the Body Snatchers]]'' (1956).<ref name="Cull: Media History, 200" /> According to Mark Bould, the series "seemed in tune with a decade of [[civil disobedience]] and [[anti-imperialist]] [[guerrilla war]]s"<ref name="Cambridge" /> – a view supported by Rebecca Feasey of the [[University of Edinburgh]], who has written that it is one of a number of series that "exploited the fears of 1960s America by presenting civil disobedience and the potentially negative impact of new technologies."<ref name="Masculinity">{{cite book|last=Feasey|first=Rebecca|title=Masculinity and Popular Television|publisher=[[Edinburgh University Press]]|year=2009|page=57|isbn=978-0-7486-2798-1|chapter=Science Fiction and Fantasy Television: Challenging Dominant Gender Roles}}</ref> Since 2001, comparisons have been made to the [[September 11 attacks]], as well as the ensuing [[War on Terror]].<ref name="ToonhoundEntry" /><ref name="THound01" />
To other reviewers, ''Captain Scarlet'' remains a "[[Camp (style)|camp]] classic"<ref name="Rampton">{{cite news|last1=Rampton |first1=James |title=Briefing: Magical Mysteron Tour |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/television--briefing-magical-mysteron-tour-1508077.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |location=London |date=1 October 1993 |accessdate=3 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m031rXLE?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/television--briefing-magical-mysteron-tour-1508077.html |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="SoundandVision">{{cite book|last=Frith|first=Simon|authorlink=Simon Frith|editor1-last=Frith|editor1-first=Simon|editor2-last=Goodwin|editor2-first=Andrew|editor3-last=Grossberg|editor3-first=Lawrence|editor3-link=Lawrence Grossberg|title=Sound & Vision: the Music Video Reader|publisher=Routledge|location=London|year=1993|page=66|isbn=978-0-415-09431-3|chapter=Youth/Music/Television}}</ref> that, in Bould's opinion, relates well to other Anderson productions due to a common depiction of "a [[utopia]]n future benefiting from [[World government in science fiction|world government]], high technology, [[ethnic diversity]], and a generally positive sense of [[Americanisation]]. They articulate the commonly made connection between technological developments and economic prosperity."<ref name="Bould, 219">Bould, p. 219.</ref> He also states that ''Captain Scarlet'' espouses "Euro-cool [[consumerism]]".<ref name="Cambridge" /> The concept of world government is common to Anderson's work and was inspired by his thoughts on the matter at the time: "I had all sorts of fancy ideas about the future ... we had the [[United Nations]] and I imagined that the world would come together and there would be a world government."<ref name="Cull: British Science Fiction Television: a Hitchhiker's Guide, 121">Cull 2006, p. 121.</ref> Peter Wright, on the series' depiction of technology, notes the "qualified [[technophilia]]" that it shares with ''Thunderbirds''.<ref name="Wright">{{cite book|last=Wright|first=Peter|editor1-last=Bould|editor1-first=Mark|editor2-last=Butler|editor2-first=Andrew M.|editor3-last=Roberts|editor3-first=Adam|title=The Routledge Companion to Science Fiction|year=2009|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]], 2009|location=Oxford|isbn=978-0-415-45378-3|page=98|chapter=Film and Television, 1960–1980}}</ref>
Since its first appearance, ''Captain Scarlet'' has been criticised for its filming, which has been considered too static due to the problem of moving the [[Supermarionation]] puppets convincingly.<ref name="HowsWhys" /><ref name="Clark">{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Anthony|title=BFI Entry|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/455572/index.html|work=[[British Film Institute|BFI]] [[screenonline]]|accessdate=3 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516090835/http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/455572/index.html|archivedate=16 May 2008|deadurl=no}}</ref> The return to a 25-minute episode format, as had been the case with series preceding ''Thunderbirds'', has been blamed for a perceived drop in quality of storytelling and a lack of [[subplot]]s.<ref name="Clark" /><ref name="Peel, 246">Peel, p. 246.</ref> Concerns have also been raised about the development of the characters: in a 1986 interview, script editor [[Tony Barwick]] described ''Captain Scarlet'' as "hard-nosed stuff"<ref name="Bentley, 31" /> that lacked humour, stating, "It was all for the American market and to that extent there was no deep [[characterisation]]. [The characters] all balanced one against the other."<ref name="Bentley, 31" /> To Jeff Evans, writer of ''The Penguin TV Companion'', it is "more detailed"; he explains: "The agents were given private lives and real identities, and were furnished with other biographical data."<ref name="PenTVCom">{{cite book|last=Evans|first=Jeff|title=The Penguin TV Companion|year=2003|publisher=[[Penguin Books]]|isbn=978-0-14-101221-6|page=119}}</ref>
{{Quote box|quote=While it would become a huge success, ''Captain Scarlet'' received a less than enthusiastic reception from critics. It caused a stir among parents, who condemned the show for its realistic carnage, and (some) children who were bemused by its gritty realism.|salign=right|source=– Chris Drake and Graeme Bassett (1993)<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 290">Drake and Bassett, p. 290.</ref>|width=17.5%|align=left}}
Science-fiction author [[John Peel (writer)|John Peel]] considers ''Captain Scarlet'' inferior to ''Thunderbirds'', arguing that although the [[special effects]] had improved, it was to the detriment of the scriptwriting. He compares this schism to the disappointing reception to [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]'' (1984) following the success of ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'' (1981):<ref name="Peel, 245">Peel, p. 245.</ref> "Anderson made the same mistake that [[George Lucas]] made, assuming that if the effects were praised in ''Thunderbirds'', the public wanted a show with more effects."<ref name="Peel, 245" /> Peel also finds fault with the nature of Scarlet himself, suggesting that the use of an "indestructible" hero made the conclusions to the episodes too predictable.<ref name="Peel, 246" /> Furthermore, he expresses a concern that Scarlet, who is often seen to risk his life in a bid to thwart Mysteron plots, served as a poor role model to a target audience of impressionable children.<ref name="Peel, 246" />
Seen as a [[Cult following|cult]] series by some critics,<ref name="BritYouthTV">{{cite book|last=Lury|first=Karen|title=British Youth Television: Cynicism and Enchantment|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2001|page=119|isbn=978-0-19-815970-4|chapter=The 'Television Presenter': the Post-Modern Performer}}</ref> ''Captain Scarlet'' ranked 33rd in a 2007 ''[[Radio Times]]'' poll to determine the greatest science-fiction series of all time.<ref name="RadioTimes">{{cite web|title=''Radio Times'': Sci-Fi Survey results |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/content/features/sci-fi-survey/ |work=[[Radio Times|radiotimes.com]] |year=2007 |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lzzY1ihB?url=http://www.radiotimes.com/content/features/sci-fi-survey/ |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Despite concerns that it is not a true "[[Children's television series|children's]]" series on account of its "dark" tone and violence,<ref name="Lesterdemon" /><ref name="h2g2" /> it appeared in 51st position in the 2001 Channel 4 list show ''100 Greatest Kids' TV Shows''.<ref name="100Kids">{{cite web|title=''100 Greatest Kids' TV Shows'': Results|url=http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/kidstv/results.html|work=channel4.com|publisher=Channel 4|year=2001|accessdate=28 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803013457/http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/kidstv/results.html|archivedate=3 August 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Judging ''Captain Scarlet'' next to its immediate predecessor, ''Thunderbirds'', Gerry Anderson's own verdict is unambiguous: "Nothing was as successful as ''Thunderbirds''. ''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons'' was very successful, but once you've had a smash hit, everything tends to look less successful in comparison."<ref name="Bentley: Thunderbirds, 41">{{cite book|last1=Bentley|first1=Chris|title=The Complete Book of Thunderbirds|publisher=[[Carlton Books]]|location=London|edition=2nd|year=2005|origyear=2000|isbn=978-1-84442-454-2|page=41}}</ref>
===Puppets=== Turning his attention to [[Sylvia Anderson]]'s costume design, Bould praises the "commitment to fashion" evident throughout the Anderson series, singling out the design of the Spectrum Angel uniforms.<ref name="Bould, 220">Bould, p. 220.</ref> The realistic design of the new puppets has been praised by Vincent Terrace<ref name="CrimeTV">{{cite book|last=Terrace|first=Vincent|title=Crime Fighting Heroes of Television: Over 10,000 Facts from 151 Shows, 1949–2001|publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]|location=North Carolina|year=2002|page=43|isbn=978-0-7864-1395-9}}</ref> and criticised by others. Certain members of the production staff had the impression that they lacked the charm of the earlier generation of puppets due to the authentic proportions that were now being used.<ref name="Bentley, 14" /> Director [[David Lane (director)|David Lane]]'s initial thoughts on a prototype, sculpted by head puppet-maker John Brown,<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 151" /> were, "it was as if there was a little dead person in [the box] ... because it was perfect in all its proportions it just looked odd."<ref name="Bentley, 14" /> Brown remembers placing the prototype next to the [[Lady Penelope]] puppet from ''Thunderbirds'' and gauging the response from colleagues:<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 151" /> "When they saw it, some people were horrified by the difference. Some didn't like it, some did."<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 151" /><ref name="Teletronic" /> Commentators have noted that facial expression was sacrificed in favour of a realistic design,<ref name="h2g2">{{cite web|title=''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons'' – Background to the TV Series|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A786486|work=[[BBC Online]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=12 August 2002|accessdate=1 October 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070806034845/http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A786486|archivedate=6 August 2007|deadurl=no}}</ref> a result on which Terry Curtis remembers:
{{Quote|The changes of expression on those puppets had to be perfect and in no way exaggerated like the old ones were. I remember when [fellow puppet designer] Tim Cooksey did Colonel White, he had a lot of trouble doing different expressions as the face was just so realistic. I had a similar problem with [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Blue]]. I remember I did a Blue "smiler" head and people could hardly tell the difference between that and the normal one.<ref name="Bentley, 16" />}}
Sculptor John Blundall has called the new puppet design "ridiculous",<ref name="Teletronic" /><ref name="Archer and Hearn, 152">Archer and Hearn, p. 152.</ref> criticising Anderson's attempts to make the puppets appear more lifelike on the basis that "We always try to do with puppets what you can't do with humans."<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 152" /> Expressing a preference for the design ''Thunderbirds'' era,<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 152" /> Blundall agrees that the transition from [[caricature]] to realism was at the expense of "character and personality",<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 152" /> asserting that "If the puppet appears completely natural, the audience no longer has to use its imagination."<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 152" /> Anderson states that he pushed for the reshaping of the puppets to please viewers,<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 152" /> deeming it not "a case of moving to a new technique, but more a case of incorporating new ideas with existing methods."<ref name="Archer and Hearn, 152" /> Evans praises the new puppets, describing them as "perfect in proportion" and commending the fact the electronic circitry was now in the puppets' bodies.<ref name="PenTVCom" />
Summing up ''Captain Scarlet'' as "better puppets, bigger [[Action (fiction)|action]] and a huge step backwards in stories" compared to ''Thunderbirds'',<ref name="Peel, 244">Peel, p. 244.</ref> Peel disputes the claim that the next generation of puppets mark a failure on the part of the series,<ref name="Peel, 245" /> arguing that the increased realism could not have deterred an audience familiar with the previous design.<ref name="Peel, 245" /> Although to his mind the characterisation was less endearing,<ref name="Peel, 245" /> Peel suggests that it is an over-emphasis on the visual, at the expense of characterisation, that truly accounts for the reduced credibility of ''Captain Scarlet''.<ref name="Peel, 245" />
===Race, gender and symbolism=== {{Quote box|quote=When I made ''[[Supercar (TV series)|Supercar]]'' for [[Associated Television|ATV]], we put a number of black characters in an episode because the story demanded it. ATV had an American advisor at the time, and he made us take out every black character and replace them with white characters and white voices. He said he would not be able to sell it to stations in the [[Southern United States|South]] ... I was always very anxious to promote racial harmony, so as soon as people had become more sensible I took advantage of it.|salign=right|source=– [[Gerry Anderson]] (1993)<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 204">Drake and Bassett, p. 204.</ref>|width=25%|align=right}}
During its 1993 UK repeat run, ''Captain Scarlet'' attracted attention with regard to the [[black-and-white dualism]] debate for its use of the codenames "White" to designate the head of Spectrum, [[Colonel White]], and "Black" for the villainous Captain Black.<ref name="Bentley, 122" /><ref name="La Rivière, 160">La Rivière, p. 160.</ref> Defending the series against the accusations of racism and [[political incorrectness]], Anderson pointed out that [[Lieutenant Green]], Melody Angel and Harmony Angel are among the heroes of the series in spite of their African and Asian backgrounds.<ref name="Bentley, 122" /> Green is the only male black character to be given a substantial role in any series produced by Anderson.<ref name="Archer, 32iii">Archer, p. 32iii.</ref>
In academic works, the diversity of the Spectrum personnel in terms of both race and gender has been viewed highly.<ref name="WomenInSpace">{{cite book|last1=Shayler|first1=David|authorlink1=David Shayler|last2=Moule|first2=Ian A.|title=Women in Space: Following Valentina|publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media]]|year=2005|page=xvii|isbn=978-1-85233-744-5}}</ref> Bould praises the series for its "beautiful, [[multiethnic]], female Angel fighter pilots"<ref name="Bould, 220" /> and "secondary roles played by capable women."<ref name="Bould, 220" /> In an interview conducted in 2003, Anderson confirmed that a conscious effort was made to feature ethnic minorities: "... I think people who make television programmes have a responsibility, particularly when children are watching avidly and you know their minds can be affected almost irreversibly as they grow up. We were very conscious of introducing different ethnic backgrounds."<ref name="Cull: British Science Fiction Television: a Hitchhiker's Guide, 127">Cull 2006, p. 127.</ref>
Guyanese actor [[Cy Grant]], who voiced the character of Lieutenant Green and believed that ''Captain Scarlet'' had positive multicultural value,<ref name="CGWeb" /><ref name="La Rivière, 160" /> discussed the [[allegorical]] nature of the series.<ref name="CGWeb" /> According to him, Christian symbolism was heavily implied, with Colonel White assuming the role of [[God in Christianity|God]], opposed by the [[Christian teaching about the Devil|Devil]] in the form of Captain Black and descended by Captain Scarlet, who serves as a [[Christ]] allegory; moreover, [[Cloudbase]] represented [[Heaven#In Christianity|Heaven]] and was guarded by its own fleet of [[Angel#Christianity|Angels]].<ref name="CGWeb" /><ref name="La Rivière, 160" /> Grant has also lionised Green as an African trickster hero.<ref name="CGWeb" /> On dualism, he argued, "the '[[darkness]]' of the Mysterons is most easily seen as the psychological rift – the struggle of [[Good and evil|'good' and 'evil']] – of the [[Western world]] as personified by Colonel White and his team. Dark and [[Light (theology)|light]] are but aspects of each other. Incidentally, green is the colour of nature that can heal that rift."<ref name="La Rivière, 160" />
==Other media== [[File:Dinky Toys 103 Spectrum Patrol Car-Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons.jpg|thumb|[[Dinky Toys]] version of the [[Spectrum Saloon Car (SSC)|Spectrum Patrol Car]] (or Spectrum Saloon Car, SPC or SSC), the primary [[escort vehicle]] of Spectrum|alt=The photograph depicts a scale toy replica of an unarmoured, futuristic car that is deep red in colour and incorporates an angular bonnet and roof.]]
Since the 1960s, the TV series has been supplemented by tie-in merchandise, example products ranging from toy dolls<ref name="Marketing">{{cite news|last1=Jones |first1=Helen |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/nostalgia-is-the-bestselling-game-of-all-marketing-captain-scarlet-and-action-man-are-among-the-successful-new-toys-this-christmas-that-will-be-familiar-to-many-parents-1467013.html |title=Nostalgia is the Best-Selling Game of All: Marketing Captain Scarlet and Action Man are Among the Successful "New" Toys this Christmas that will be Familiar to Many Parents |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |location=London |date=12 December 1993 |accessdate=19 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nf4eItBQ?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/nostalgia-is-the-bestselling-game-of-all-marketing-captain-scarlet-and-action-man-are-among-the-successful-new-toys-this-christmas-that-will-be-familiar-to-many-parents-1467013.html |archivedate=19 February 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> to a [[Vehicular combat game|driving-themed]] video game, released for the [[PlayStation 2]] platform in 2006.<ref name="Blast">{{cite web|title=Blast! ''Captain Scarlet''|url=http://www.blast-games.com/en/product.asp?pid=422|work=blast-games.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080419011218/http://www.blast-games.com/en/product.asp?pid=422|archivedate=19 April 2008|accessdate=19 February 2010|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="Gamespot">{{cite web |title=''Captain Scarlet'' Tech Info |url=http://uk.gamespot.com/ps2/adventure/captainscarlet/tech_info.html |work=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=19 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qO9iSdj9?url=http://uk.gamespot.com/ps2/adventure/captainscarlet/tech_info.html |archivedate=10 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> The ATV game show ''[[The Golden Shot]]'', presented by [[Bob Monkhouse]], adopted ''Captain Scarlet'' as the theme for its 1967 Christmas special. Broadcast live on 23 December, the programme featured guest appearances from [[Francis Matthews (actor)|Francis Matthews]] and "The Spectrum", who performed their latest single, "Headin' for a Heatwave".<ref name="Bentley, 94">Bentley 2001, p. 94.</ref>
===Audio episodes=== To complement the TV episodes, [[AP Films#Century 21|Century 21]] released five further ''Captain Scarlet'' stories as [[Radio drama|audio adventure]]s on [[vinyl record]] [[Extended play|EP]]s, each running to approximately 21 minutes,<ref name="Bentley, 93">Bentley 2001, p. 93.</ref> and starring the original voice cast,<ref name="Bentley, 93" /> in 1967.<ref name="Bentley, 93" /> ''[[TV Century 21]]'' script editor [[Angus P. Allan]] wrote ''Introducing Captain Scarlet'' (which is set during the dénouement to "[[The Mysterons (Captain Scarlet episode)|The Mysterons]]" with the inclusion of [[Flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]] to provide [[Exposition (narrative)|exposition]]),<ref name="Bentley, 94" /> ''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons'' and ''Captain Scarlet of Spectrum'',<ref name="Bentley, 93" /> while ''Captain Scarlet is Indestructible'' and ''Captain Scarlet versus Captain Black'' were scripted by his assistant, Richard O'Neill.<ref name="Bentley, 93" />
===Books and comics=== In the late 1960s, three tie-in novels were published under the pen name "John Theydon", a pseudonym for author John William Jennison,<ref name="Bentley, 109">Bentley 2001, p. 109.</ref> titled ''Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons'' (1967), ''Captain Scarlet and the Silent Saboteur'' (1967) and ''The Angels and the Creeping Enemy'' (1968).<ref name="Titles">All titles as published in ''The Complete Book of Captain Scarlet'' (2001), by Chris Bentley, pp. 109–111.</ref><ref name="SHBooksComics">{{cite web|last=Bishop|first=Chris|title=Merchandising: Books & Magazines|url=http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/books.html|work=spectrum-headquarters.com|date=25 February 2008|accessdate=6 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612175958/http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/books.html|archivedate=12 June 2008|deadurl=no}}</ref> As implied by its title, the third novel places the focus on the Spectrum Angels as the primary protagonists.<ref name="SHBooksComics" /> Later, in 1993, Young [[Random House|Corgi Books]] published four novelisations, targeted at children, based upon the original series episodes "The Mysterons", "[[Lunarville 7]]", "[[Noose of Ice]]" and "[[The Launching]]".<ref name="SHBooksComics" />
''Captain Scarlet'' also formed the basis of three [[comic strip]]s drawn for the weekly children's comic, ''TV Century 21''.<ref name="Bentley, 102" /> Spanning 17 issues (numbers 141–157) from September 1967 to January 1968, the strip adventures were written by Angus P. Allan with artwork by [[Ron Embleton]], and were titled ''We Will Destroy Unity City'', ''We Will Destroy the Observatory Network'' and ''We Shall Make Earth a Planet of Silence''.<ref name="Bentley, 102" /> Following the end of the TV series, the comic continued the story of the ''Captain Scarlet'' universe, with later strips revealing that the [[Mysteron]]s deactivate their Martian complex and relinquish their control over [[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]], while Scarlet himself leaves Spectrum to make use of his powers in the fight against Earth-bound criminals and threats.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 280" /> The Mysterons ultimately re-awaken, prompting Scarlet and Spectrum to resume their struggle.<ref name="Drake and Bassett, 280" />
A [[manga]] adaptation of the series, titled ''Captain Scarlet'', ran in the Japanese ''[[Shōnen Book]]'' anthology from January to August 1968.<ref name="SHManga">{{cite web|last=Bishop|first=Chris|title=Cast of Characters: Captain Scarlet|url=http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/captain_scarlet.html|work=spectrum-headquarters.com|date=26 July 2005|accessdate=6 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612171939/http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/captain_scarlet.html|archivedate=12 June 2008|deadurl=no}}</ref> Century 21 published [[Annual publication|annuals]] based on the series between 1967 and 1969,<ref name="SHBooksComics" /> while the original ''Captain Scarlet'' comic strips were reprinted in the 1968 and 1969 editions of ''TV21 Annual''.<ref name="SHBooksComics" /> Further annuals, published in 1993 and 1994 by Grandreams,<ref name="SHBooksComics" /> coincided with the [[BBC2]] repeats of the TV episodes.<ref name="SHBooksComics" /> In 2002, [[Carlton Books]] released a new edition to accompany the digitally remastered broadcasts that had started in 2001.<ref name="SHBooksComics" />
===Home video=== In the United Kingdom, [[Carlton Video]] commercially released the series, as both eight separate volumes and as a "Complete Series Box Set",<ref name="Bentley, 128">Bentley 2001, p. 128.</ref><ref name="SHVideos">{{cite web|last=Bishop|first=Chris|title=Merchandising – Multimedias: Videos|url=http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/videos.html|work=spectrum-headquarters.com|date=19 May 2002|accessdate=22 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080510221300/http://www.spectrum-headquarters.com/videos.html|archivedate=10 May 2008|deadurl=no}}</ref> from September 2001 to March 2002.<ref name="Bentley, 128" /><ref name="SHVideos" /> Presented with the same remastered video and audio quality that was introduced for the [[BBC Two]] repeats of 2001,<ref name="Bentley, 125" /> the box set incorporates a ninth tape including ''The Indestructible Captain Scarlet'', a special programme that describes Spectrum, the Mysterons and the events of the TV series.<ref name="SHVideos" /> Earlier releases, marketed by [[PolyGram]] and "Channel 5",<ref name="SHVideos" /> had numbered the episodes in an order different from that of the 1960s broadcasts<ref name="SHVideos" /> and, in the case of the first two volumes, had added to them with the insertion of footage specially filmed for the [[ITC Entertainment|ITC]] ''Captain Scarlet'' [[compilation film]]s of the 1980s.<ref name="SHVideos" />
Since September 2001, ''Captain Scarlet'' has also been available in five volumes on [[PAL]] [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] DVD, also marketed by Carlton,<ref name="SHDVD" /><ref name="Bentley, 128" /> with a new [[Dolby]] 5.1 Surround Sound sound mix to complement the original mono track.<ref name="SHDVD" /><ref name="DVDDetails">{{cite web|last=LeVasseur |first=Andrea |title=''Captain Scarlet'' Region 1 DVD Release Information |url=http://www.allmovie.com/dvd/captain-scarlet-4-discs-25250 |work=AllMovie |accessdate=22 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m03OjHAV?url=http://www.allmovie.com/dvd/captain-scarlet-4-discs-25250 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Special features for these releases include [[Audio commentary|audio commentaries]] with [[Gerry Anderson]] for the episodes "The Mysterons" and "[[Attack on Cloudbase]]", the five audio episodes from 1967, behind-the-scenes production photos, information about original ITC advertising and merchandise, and 1960s [[TV spot]]s.<ref name="SHDVD" /> As with the VHS releases, the five DVD volumes have also received a box set edition, which incorporates a bonus sixth disc including ''Captain Scarlet S.I.G.''<ref name="DVDSubs">{{cite web|title=''Captain Scarlet'' Region 2 DVD Release Information |url=http://dvd-subtitles.com/captain-scarlet-and-the-mysterons-the-complete-series-box-set-d3970.html |work=dvd-subtitles.com |date=30 December 2005 |accessdate=22 November 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5m03GX98K?url=http://dvd-subtitles.com/captain-scarlet-and-the-mysterons-the-complete-series-box-set-d3970.html |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> (a behind-the-scenes documentary produced and presented by Gerry Anderson) and five sets of alternative opening credits.<ref name="SHDVD" />
The special features of the four-disc [[NTSC]] North American Region 1 edition of the box set, released by [[A&E Television Networks|A&E Home Video]] in 2002,<ref name="Billboard" /><ref name="DVDDetails" /> are mostly similar to those of the Region 2 version, with the additions of a text-based "Introduction to Captain Scarlet" and DVD-ROM content.<ref name="DVDDetails" /><ref name="DigiMonkey">{{cite web|title=Digital Monkey Box Presents ''Captain Scarlet''|url=http://www.digitalmonkeybox.com/captain_scarlet.htm|work=digitalmonkeybox.com|accessdate=22 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115090623/http://digitalmonkeybox.com/captain_scarlet.htm|archivedate=15 November 2007|deadurl=no}}</ref> In 2004, [[Imavision]] unveiled a French-language edition of the box set aimed at the Canadian market.<ref name="SHDVD" /> The set is also available in Japan on Region 2 (as six discs)<ref name="SHDVD" /> and Australia on Region 4 (as five discs).<ref name="SHDVD" />
In September 2017, to coincide with the series' 50th anniversary, [[Network Distributing]] announced that it would be releasing ''Captain Scarlet'' on [[Blu-ray Disc]] in the UK, with the episodes restored from the original 35 mm film [[Negative (photography)|negatives]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gerryanderson.co.uk/classic-captain-scarlet-blu-ray-way/|title=Classic ''Captain Scarlet'' Blu-ray on the Way!|last1=Anderson|first1=Jamie|author1-link=Jamie Anderson (producer)|work=gerryanderson.co.uk|publisher=[[Anderson Entertainment]]|date=29 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180128092054/http://gerryanderson.co.uk/classic-captain-scarlet-blu-ray-way/|archivedate=28 January 2018|deadurl=no|accessdate=14 June 2018}}</ref>

film)|''Thunderbirds'' film]] released in 2004, but the idea has not been developed since.
===Compilation films=== {{Main|Captain Scarlet vs. the Mysterons|Revenge of the Mysterons from Mars}}
In 1980, the New York offices of ITC, under the supervision of [[Robert Mandell]],<ref name="Bentley, 121">Bentley 2001, p. 121.</ref> combined episodes from the original series to make two [[compilation film]]s for American audiences, with the aim of reviving transatlantic [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]] sales.<ref name="Bentley, 121" /> This became common practice for Anderson productions during the 1980s, with [[made-for-television]] films comprising episodes of ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]'' and ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' airing to US [[Cable television in the United States|cable]] audiences under the generic promotional banner of "Super Space Theater".<ref name="Bentley: Episode Guide, 361">Bentley 2008, p. 361.</ref> On 24 November 1988, the second ''Captain Scarlet'' film, ''[[Revenge of the Mysterons from Mars]]'', was broadcast as the second episode of the American television series ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'', from [[Minneapolis]], on station [[KTMA]].
===CGI test film and series=== {{Main|Gerry Anderson's New Captain Scarlet}}
In 1999, [[Gerry Anderson]] supervised the production of a short [[computer-animated]] test film, ''Captain Scarlet and the Return of the Mysterons'', to explore the possibility of updating a number of his 1960s [[Supermarionation]] series for a 21st-century audience.<ref name="Bentley, 123">Bentley 2001, p. 123.</ref><ref name="Teletronic5">{{cite web|last=Marcus|first=Laurence|title=Gerry Anderson: The Puppet Master – Part 5|url=http://www.teletronic.co.uk/gerryanderson5.htm|work=teletronic.co.uk|date=June 2006|accessdate=22 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071030130851/http://www.teletronic.co.uk/gerryanderson5.htm|archivedate=30 October 2007 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> The [[working title]] was ''Captain Scarlet – The New Millennium''.<ref name="Teletronic5" /> Produced in London by the [[Moving Picture Company]],<ref name="Bentley, 123" /> the film features [[Francis Matthews (actor)|Francis Matthews]] and [[Ed Bishop]] reprising the roles of Captains [[Captain Scarlet (character)|Scarlet]] and [[Captain Blue (Captain Scarlet)|Blue]].<ref name="ToonhoundEntry" /><ref name="Teletronic5" /> Made using a combination of [[Autodesk Maya|Maya]] 3D computer graphics software and [[motion-capture]] technology,<ref name="Bentley, 124">Bentley 2001, p. 124.</ref><ref name="Teletronic5" /> the plot commences a few years after the [[Mysteron]]s end their hostilities against [[Earth]], but the reappearance of [[Captain Black (Captain Scarlet)|Captain Black]] sets the stage for a revival of the war with [[Mars]].<ref name="Bentley, 124" /> Although the film has yet to receive a [[home video]] release, it was publicly screened at a [[Fanderson]] convention in 2000<ref name="Bentley, 125" /><ref name="SHADO-USECC" /><ref name="Teletronic5" /> and at a science lecture in 2001.<ref name="Bentley, 125" />
Plans for a full CGI ''Captain Scarlet'' television series to follow the test film finally resulted in ''Gerry Anderson's New Captain Scarlet''. A [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]] of the original series, this was first broadcast in the United Kingdom on the Saturday-morning [[CITV]] programme, ''[[Ministry of Mayhem]]'', from 12 February 2005.<ref name="Bentley: Episode Guide, 282">Bentley 2008, p. 282.</ref> Produced by "Anderson Entertainment" and the "Indestructible Production Company",<ref name="Teletronic5" /><ref name="Bentley: Episode Guide, 281">Bentley 2008, p. 281.</ref> the animation used to create the series is billed in the credits as "[[Hypermarionation]]"<ref name="Bentley: Episode Guide, 281" /> to acknowledge the 1960s puppet technique, Supermarionation.<ref name="Bentley: Episode Guide, 281" />

Modern day secular and rationalist [[Kerala|Keralites]] use Dinkan to mock organized religion and religious intolerance. ==History== Dinkan (ഡിങ്കൻ) was created by story-writer N. Somashekharan and artist Baby in 1983. Dinkan was one of the earliest superhero characters created in [[Indian comics|India]] and it quickly became popular among children. He was a naughty mouse, who wasn't disciplined. During one of his escapades, Dinkan was abducted by aliens from an unknown planet. They conducted experiments on him which ended up giving him superior strength, enhanced senses and the ability to fly. Somehow Dinkan found himself back in Pankila forest and he decided to use his powers for the well-being of animals in the forest. ==Dinkoism== {{main article|Dinkoism}} Dinkoism has emerged as a [[parody religion]] on social networks organized by some atheists in [[Kerala]], India.
